card.title: Heal Your Childhood Trauma
card.description: Free yourself and start living a happier life

preview.title: Heal Your Childhood Trauma
preview.overview: This series of daily interactive stories will provide you with practical tools and mindfulness tips to help you overcome childhood trauma and start living a more fulfilling and happy life. Start this course to find out the secret to better relationships with yourself and others. Gain confidence, improve self-image, and achieve inner peace.

episodes.title: Intro: Roots of Inner Wounds
episodes.description: Starting your healing journey

content.text: Now is the time to take the first meaningful step towards overcoming childhood trauma and becoming a strong, confident, and successful individual bursting with love and life.
Our parents, siblings, friends, and teachers all have an influence on our behavior. And, as we grow older, we create patterns and keep repeating such behaviors.
In this course, we are going explore how childhood experiences can shape who we are as adults, how we view the world, and how we can use these insights to improve our lives
Let's see how our childhood experiences can affect us in adulthood
Let’s meet two people: Andy and Sandy.
Sandy grew up in an abusive household. She learned how to hide her emotions and suppress her voice.
Andy was raised in a loving and supportive environment. He learned how to be confident and trust himself and others.
New story text

explanation.text: When children are acknowledged and encouraged, they feel like their achievements and efforts have a value which boosts their self-worth.
explanation.header: Correct! Andy would be more confident.

explanation.text: As children, our caregivers shape our perception of self. Sandy felt that she was treated unfairly, which made her feel worthless.

content.question: Who is more likely to have grown up with a strong sense of self-worth?

content.text: New story text
content.question: Who is more likely to have developed a personality that’s very reserved and shy?

explanation.text: Children who grow up in a healthy household tend to have higher self-esteem and confidence than those who were abused.
Demanding and overly strict parents who bully and isolate their children produce shy adults.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Who is more likely to mistrust their partner?

explanation.text: Trust issues are often rooted in childhood trauma. Negative experiences make it difficult for children to connect with others, which ultimately leads to mistrust as adults

Adults have trust issues because they were betrayed by someone they trusted as a child or were taught that the world was a dangerous place by their parents.  You can change your life by learning to express yourself, trust your intuition, and heal from childhood trauma.
explanation.header: Yes. Sandy would be more likely to have trust issues.

content.text: You can change your life by learning to express yourself, trust your intuition, and heal from childhood trauma.
Practicing mindfulness, processing emotions, fixing the negative mindset is the solution. And we've prepared some powerful tools for you!
To better illustrate how childhood affects us and what we can do to improve our adult lives, we've prepared some interesting interactive stories. Learning has never been so easy and fun!
We've created a special approach for you to overcome childhood trauma and become a strong, confident, and successful individual bursting with love and life.
Meditation, journaling, challenging negative thoughts, affirmations... And this is just the tip of the iceberg!
Each day, you will be given a simple yet efficient task to start practicing these mindfulness techniques right away!
We also encourage you to text our mental coach if you have any questions or need more help and guidance.

content.header: Why do you need all of this?
content.text:
By the end of this course, you’ll be able to:
1) Improve relationships
2) Overcome loneliness
3) Reduce stress and worry
4) Increase confidence
To start your journey and overcome childhood trauma, it's important to start with baby steps.

Growing up in an abusive environment damages a child’s self-confidence. As you navigate our course, you’ll gain the strength to break free from the chains of insecurity and embrace a new, bold, confident version of you.
content.question: Here are several options for you to start. What do you feel like doing first? Choose an option, and we'll explain the details.

explanation.text: A tidier space can make for a more relaxed mind. Go over your apartment, and find 30 items you need to get rid of. These could be checks, old clothes, stuff you don't use anymore, garbage, and other items you need to throw away.  This will help you feel calmer, happier, and more in control.

Let's write a letter. Think of a person or a group of people who made you feel hurt or upset. Express all of your feelings, using 'I sentences': I feel hurt by... I feel sad when... I want... . Finish the letter by stating that you choose not to focus on this anymore, and this won't hold you back anymore, add why. Explain how your life will change for the better after you let go of this hurt. Then, you can keep this letter to revise it when your mind goes back to that hurt and focus on why you chose to let go of it.

Meditation is a powerful tool to help you calm down, release negative emotions, and feel relieved. We have a variety of different meditation courses and singles on the 'Discover tab' for you to choose from. Note, there is a '28-Day Childhood Trauma' meditation course to help you overcome childhood trauma, make sure to check it out!

answerOptions.text: I’ll skip the task for today

explanation.text: Don’t worry, we’ve prepared other fun and useful activities. Let's start next time then! We highly encourage you to try and practice them in the next Days to make your healing process more efficient.

content.text: This experience will be not only healing but also fun and rewarding. We have more practices and tips in store for you. In Day 2, we'll focus more on how you can become more confident to achieve anything you want in life.
“Today is your opportunity to build the tomorrow you want.”
content.title: Ken Poirot:

episodes.title: Confidence
episodes.description: Fixing the "I'm not good enough" mindset

content.text: Hello, and thank you for joining us. We are so happy you’re here!

Let’s talk about how growing up with over-demanding parents can negatively affect our confidence levels. Then we will go through a series of steps to help you regain your sense of self and skyrocket your confidence!

Did you feel like your parents were constantly on your back? Did they criticize everything you did and had unreasonable expectations? Did they put a lot of pressure on you to succeed? Did they make you feel ‌you weren’t good enough?

content.header: Side Effects From Childhood to Adulthood
content.text: Children with over-demanding parents think that nothing they do will ever be enough, so they experience a constant feeling of guilt. As they grow up, they demand too much from themselves, often beyond their physical, mental, and financial abilities. This can cause increased levels of stress and  worry and decreased confidence.
Overbearing parents can impact anyone, no matter how strong or independent you may be. Although it can be tough to heal from overbearing parents, it is possible!

Daniel’s parents were both successful in their careers. His mother was a psychologist, and his father was a professor of economics at a prestigious university. Both had very high expectations of Daniel.

From the time Daniel remembers, his parents constantly told him what he should or shouldn’t do. They forced him to spend all his free time studying. “They never let me do anything that wasn’t important to them.”

explanation.text: Over-demanding parents restrict or control the way their children wish to express themselves. This causes children to grow up with a lack of self-confidence.
Over-demanding parents restrict or control the way their children wish to express themselves. This causes children to grow up with a lack of self-confidence.

content.question: Do you agree with their parenting style?

content.text: Daniel had difficulty escaping the guilt, judgment, criticism, and blame in his home. As a result, he became a perfectionist and overachiever. Unfortunately, his perfect grades were rooted in his fear of disappointing his parents. “I felt pressured to be the perfect son.”

content.question: As a child, Daniel felt

explanation.text: It’s difficult for the children of over-demanding parents to relax because they feel like they are constantly being watched and judged.
High levels of stress often follow children throughout adulthood.

content.text: In college, Daniel tried to make friends with people, but they didn’t seem to understand the pressure he was under. He found it difficult to feel comfortable around people who didn’t know what it was like to have parents who were constantly hovering over them. “I felt like I was drowning, but I couldn’t tell anyone how I felt. I felt like a fraud, pretending like everything was fine.”

content.question: Why doesn’t Daniel tell his parents how he feels?

explanation.text: It’s natural for children to want to be accepted by their parents. Daniel wants their love, not negative judgment, so he hides his true feelings.
Daniel thinks his parents may view him as weak or unworthy if he talks about his mental struggles.

content.text: Daniel’s parents were all smiles during his college graduation ceremony. But it wasn’t long before they insisted ‌he secure a position at a distinguished company. When he got a job, his parents kept pushing him to get promoted. “They wanted me to succeed, but I didn’t know how.”

content.question: How do you think Daniel’s coworkers would describe him?

explanation.text: People who are pressured to be perfect as children feel the unrelenting need to overachieve as adults.
Adults who grew up in an over-demanding environment have a hard time being assertive and saying “no” because they lack confidence.

content.text: One day, Daniel decided to make a significant change. He gathered the courage to be honest about his feelings with his parents. He told them he ‌wanted to take a year off to travel the world and find his true purpose in life. “I am taking control of my life, and I couldn’t be happier!”

Although parents want the best for their children, they don't always know how to act and can become overbearing. It's difficult growing up with overbearing parents. They can be suffocating, critical, and always seem to be looking over your shoulder. It's no wonder many people struggle to find their way in life when overbearing parents have raised them. Follow our three-step program based on the three M’s to heal childhood wounds.

It's normal to feel angry, hurt, and resentful towards your overbearing parents. Acknowledge how your parents' behavior has made you feel and allow yourself to experience those emotions instead of repressing them. This is a critical first step in understanding how their behavior has impacted you.

Dealing with the stress of over-demanding parents may lead us to adopt unhealthy coping practices like overworking, smoking, and binging on alcohol or food. Let’s look at some mindful methods of dealing with stress and  worry.

It’s important to adopt practices that will help calm you in a healthy way. Breathing exercises, meditation, yoga, gardening, and journaling are great ways to regain control and nourish your confidence levels. Try to avoid feeling guilt, remorse, or resentment; instead, focus on being present in the here and now.
Now we are going to give you some affirmations. Take your time to memorize a handful of them and recite them out loud daily. Take a screenshot of the next screen!

I am proud of my accomplishments. I am bright, bold, and capable. My life is in my hands. Every day, I grow stronger and wiser. I inhale confidence and exhale negativity. I am not perfect, but I am worthy, and I will thrive.
It's essential to set boundaries to maintain a healthy sense of self-confidence and autonomy. Communicate openly and honestly, and be clear about what you will and will not tolerate from them.
It’s important to challenge negative thoughts that pop into your head and turn them into positive affirmations. Here you have examples of negative thoughts.

Take a look at how you can challenge a negative mindset and increase your confidence. Swapping negative thoughts with positive affirmations will help you feel better, more at peace, improve relationships, and become more successful.
New story text
content.question: How would you challenge this negative thought?

explanation.text: This is a great affirmation! However, this one doesn’t challenge the initial negative thought.

answerOptions.text: I don’t deserve to be loved

explanation.text: This is not an affirmation but ‌a negative thought that must be overcome.

answerOptions.text: I am beautiful inside and out

explanation.text: Correct! One’s appearance doesn’t define their worth. Each person is beautiful and unique in their own way. We don’t need social standards to dictate the definition of beautiful. This is how one could challenge that negative thought!

content.text: Next time you have negative thoughts, ask: “Why would I think like that?” Then try to challenge that thought. Prove it wrong! Focus on your strengths, cut yourself some slack, and try looking at things from a different perspective. Write ‌your negative thoughts and swap them with positive affirmations. Repeat those affirmations regularly!
Stick around for Day 3, where we’ll discuss a topic that’s all too common for many: loneliness and how to overcome it. See you there!
“With the realization of one’s own potential and self-confidence in one’s own ability, one can build a better world.”
content.title: Dalai Lama:

episodes.title: Loneliness
episodes.description: Building a healthy relationship with yourself and others

content.text: We’re so glad you joined us!

content.question: Do you often feel lonely?

explanation.text: Loneliness is a complicated and overwhelming emotion to deal with for many people. It can affect anyone, regardless of age, gender, or lifestyle.
Loneliness is a complicated and overwhelming emotion to deal with for many people. It can affect anyone, regardless of age, gender, or lifestyle.

content.text: Loneliness can have a negative impact on your health, both mental and physical. It can cause excessive worry, overthinking, and sleep problems. It can also lead to poorer physical health, making you more susceptible to illnesses. Moreover, it affects your ability to build and maintain fulfilling relationships.

Childhood traumas can cause a person to grow up feeling lonely and isolated from others. That’s because a child is always looking to their parents for comfort and protection, so if they experience abuse or neglect, they feel insecure and unloved. When we develop a negative view of ourselves and others, we end up feeling isolated and alone.

People who’ve had traumatic experiences may be more susceptible to loneliness as they fear rejection or abandonment. They also have a hard time trusting others and tend to be more independent and self-reliant.

Sam grew up in a home with both parents. His mother was emotionally distant. That meant she wasn’t interested in Sam’s schooling or hobbies. Sam rarely felt warmth and love from her. His father was hardly ever home. He was either at the office or on business trips. But they took a fun family vacation once a year!

explanation.text: Children who grow up in a loving environment can develop abandonment issues if a parent is constantly working or absent or if one parent has a chronic mental or physical illness.
Children who grow up in a loving environment can develop abandonment issues if a parent is constantly working or absent or if one parent has a chronic mental or physical illness.
Children who grow up in a loving environment can develop abandonment issues if a parent is constantly working or absent or if one parent has a chronic mental or physical illness.
Children who grow up in a loving environment can develop abandonment issues if a parent is constantly working or absent or if one parent has a chronic mental or physical illness.

content.question: How do you think Sam felt?

content.text: At school, kids constantly teased Sam about his appearance. As a result, he felt ‌he didn't belong with other people; he was a loner. Sam felt like he never fit in at school or at home.

content.question: How do you think Sam’s childhood loneliness affected him as an adult?

explanation.text: Sam decided he doesn’t fit in with others as a way of protecting himself so that if they leave one day, he won’t feel hurt. This unconscious way of thinking will impact his adult relationships.

answerOptions.text: He thinks people will never leave

explanation.text: People who grow up with a fear of abandonment unconsciously assume that everyone will eventually leave. This can lead to depression and loneliness in adulthood.

content.text: Sam had a string of relationships as an adult. He knew he had “commitment issues” and would run away as soon as partners expressed a desire to be exclusive. But even when Sam was in a relationship, he continued to feel lonely.

content.question: Why?

explanation.text: Some people who experience abandonment as a child believe ‌they deserve to be abandoned. As adults, they re-enact the experience of abandonment in their relationships by breaking up with their partners or choosing emotionally unavailable or abusive partners.
He keeps people at a distance so they can’t hurt him by leaving.

content.text: Sam took a break from dating and focused on healing from his childhood trauma. He learned ‌he felt unsafe, invisible, and emotionally neglected as a child. His unmet needs manifested into abandonment fears which contributed heavily to relationship issues and loneliness.
Like Sam, you can take steps to overcome loneliness and improve your relationship with others and yourself. Follow our three-step program based on the three M’s!

To learn how to overcome loneliness, you need to accept yourself just as you are. It's okay if you're not perfect! It’s okay if you didn’t have the perfect childhood! Learn to love yourself, regardless of what you look like, how old you are, or what happened to you.

You can ‌overcome your fear of abandonment by being more open to the idea of being alone. Learn to let go of the fear of being alone. Letting go of this fear allows you to overcome loneliness and feel comfortable in your own skin.

Try to focus on the good things in your life, such as your friends, family, hobbies, and talents. This can help you feel more positive and appreciated, making loneliness less overwhelming. When you're feeling down, take some time for yourself; do something you enjoy, write in your journal, or take a relaxing bath.

Combat loneliness by attempting to connect with others. Consider joining a club or group that meets regularly or volunteering for a cause that you're passionate about. This can also mean starting a conversation with someone you see regularly but don't know well or reaching out to old friends and family members. Send a short text message to your colleague or relative!
Here’s a list of activities you can use to overcome the feeling of loneliness. Take a screenshot to get back to it later!
Now we are going to suggest you several practices that can help you overcome loneliness. Consider each of them, and then you’ll choose one as your task for today!

Reaching out and sharing your feelings is essential since you might gain new insights, support, and a feeling of safety. Talk to your friend, family member, or partner. Tell them how you feel and try to figure it out together.

Reaching out and sharing your feelings is essential since you might gain new insights, support, and a feeling of safety. At the end of this session, text our mental coach, tell them about your problem, and receive professional advice.

Journaling is a great way to start! Take a pen and a piece of paper and start writing ‌your feelings. How do you feel right now? What would make you feel better? What people or activities make you feel less lonely? What can you do today to feel better? You will definitely gain new insights!

Doing activities you enjoy is a fantastic way to feel better, reconnect with yourself, and eventually overcome loneliness. Here are a couple of meditative options: creating art, gardening, yoga, reading, and stargazing. If you already have another hobby in mind, go for it! Don’t put your happiness on a shelf; start today!

Self-care is an excellent choice to learn how to be at peace with yourself and overcome loneliness. It can be physical and emotional. Physical self-care includes taking a bubble bath, having a spa day, and treating yourself to delicious foods. Emotional self-care includes journaling, meditating, reconnecting with friends or family, and unplugging for an evening. Choose a self-care practice and start today!
New story text
content.question: Which one do you choose for today?

explanation.text: Excellent choice! Talking to someone is always a good idea. You don’t have to carry your burdens alone! Get it off your chest, and you’ll feel relieved.

Excellent choice! After you finish this Day, open the “My Plan” tab, tap the speech bubble in the upper right corner and text a mental coach. This is a safe space, without judgment or pressure. A friendly coach is ready to give you a piece of advice!
Excellent choice! Extra tip: create a relaxing atmosphere. Get a cozy blanket or light up some candles. Take a few deep breaths and try following the journaling prompts we’ve given you before.

Excellent choice! Extra tip: if you are worried you won’t have enough time, don’t try to find ‘hobby time’ every day. Try thinking of time in weeks to discover extra time hidden in your schedule. This way, you'll find a few hours for something you enjoy each week.
Excellent choice! Remember, self-care doesn’t have to be complicated. Choose something that makes you feel good, relaxed, and happy

content.text: You’re well on your way to leading a happier life filled with valuable relationships! Join us for Day 3, where we will talk about toxic attractions. See you soon!
“A season of loneliness and isolation is when the caterpillar gets its wings. Remember that the next time you feel alone.”
content.title: Mandy Hale:

episodes.title: Toxic Attraction
episodes.description: Signs of a toxic relationship and what you can do

content.text: We want you to know that we are proud of you for taking steps towards healing from your childhood trauma. It might seem challenging, but you will be much happier and healthier. Keep going!

When you're attracted to someone, it's natural to want to pursue that person and see where the relationship could go. But a toxic attraction is one where you find yourself drawn to someone harmful. They might be emotionally unavailable, abusive, controlling, or simply not good for you. But for some reason, you can't seem to let go.

Toxicity is a state of being in which a negative emotion affects one or both parties. The toxicity can manifest in various ways, but there are some key feelings to look out for. Here are nine signs of a toxic relationship.

1) You always make excuses for them
2) You walk on eggshells around them
3) They're constantly putting you down or making you feel bad about yourself

4) They're unreliable, and you can never count on them
5) They're always making you feel ‌you're not good enough
6) You're always worried about what they'll do or say next

7) You have a hard time being yourself around them
8) You don't feel ‌you can trust them
9) They gaslight you

You may have heard the term “gaslighting.” It happens when a toxic person wants to manipulate or control you by making you feel unsure about your emotions and experiences. The toxic person may minimize your feelings, deny something happened, or accuse you of being too sensitive and overreacting.
New story text
content.question: Have you faced any of those signs in a relationship?

explanation.text: Let's check how to deal with those signs.

explanation.header: That's great! We hope you'll never experience them.
explanation.text: Yet sometimes we might not notice these signs. It's important to better understand what a toxic relationship might look like, so you could avoid getting into one.

content.text: Toxic attraction is often based on unresolved issues from the past or a deep-seated need for approval and validation. People may also be drawn to toxic relationships based on negative childhood experiences.

They are a cute couple! They’ve been together for three years and live in a small apartment downtown. To the outside world, they seem like a loving couple. But behind closed doors, their relationship is very different.

Max tells Julie what she can and cannot wear, where and when to go places, and who she can spend time with. He also controls the finances. At first, Julie liked the fact that he cared about her and wanted to help guide her. Now, she feels like she can’t move without his permission.

content.question: What’s toxic about this situation?

explanation.text: Someone who tries to control your life is trying to control you. You should be free to make your own decisions and take your own actions.
You should never have to live your life according to someone else’s controlling ways.

content.text: If Julie forgot to set the alarm and is late for work, she blames Max. If Julie is angry about traffic, she always blames Max. Max is tired of being scolded for things he cannot control.

content.question: Why is Julie’s behavior harmful?

explanation.text: You should never have to feel guilty when someone else is to blame.
Someone who only blames you is trying to manipulate your emotions by making you feel guilty.

content.text: Julie can’t remember the last time Max complimented her. Max criticizes almost every decision she makes. He tells her to wear less makeup one day but more makeup the next. And he’s constantly criticizing her cooking. She feels like she can’t do anything right.

content.question: Why is he doing that?

explanation.text: Someone who constantly criticizes you is trying to control you and make you feel bad about yourself. If you have low self-esteem, you are more likely to stay in a toxic situation.

answerOptions.text: He wants to lower her self-esteem

explanation.text: Toxic people don’t want you to think or act positively because they know this will change how you feel about yourself. You may gather the confidence to leave.

content.text: To be honest, Julie and Max were miserable in their cycle of toxicity. But it was Julie who packed her belongings and moved out of the apartment. She finally realized that a toxic relationship was not worth damaging her mental health and hurting Max.

content.question: So, in what ways did childhood trauma affect Julie and Max’s relationship?

answerOptions.text: Low levels of trust and self-confidence

explanation.text: Many children who have been affected by trauma grow up with low self-esteem. They tend to believe they are not good enough and will never be loved. Trauma also impacts a child’s ability to trust, which can create issues with intimacy in relationships later in life.

answerOptions.text: High levels of pride and confidence

explanation.text: Childhood trauma, such as abuse or neglect, is often passed on through toxic relationships. These relationships may cause emotional pain and low self-confidence. Toxic relationships can also create a cycle of dysfunction in a family.

content.text: The best way to get out of a toxic relationship is to be honest with yourself and realize that you are in a toxic relationship. You cannot change the other person, so you must take care of yourself. To be free from toxicity, follow our three-step plan based on the three M’s!

If you’ve experienced past trauma and toxic relationships, you will probably experience anger, sadness, fear, stress, shame, or overthinking. Accepting your emotions is the first step in dealing with your own issues. For example, you may have low self-esteem, worry, or confidence issues. You’ll need to do some work on these issues if you want to get out of a toxic relationship.

Toxic relationships are usually based on lies, so strive to stay true to yourself. A toxic person will try to get you to change your values, your beliefs, and your self-identity. Don’t let them do that. Instead, focus on yourself. We recommend meditating, journaling, hiking, or traveling somewhere new. If you feel too overwhelmed, you could also consult a therapist.

Make a list of the reasons ‌you're attracted to this person. Once you see them written out, you may realize they're not good reasons. If you feel comfortable enough, talk to the person you're attracted to about your concerns and set boundaries. If they're not listening to you and respecting your boundaries, it's time to walk away.
Your task for today is to visualize a healthy relationship, a relationship you’d like to be in.
We’ve prepared some questions for you to start. The main goal is to visualize a healthy, safe, supportive relationship.

content.header: 1. What do you expect your partner to be?
content.text:
- What features do you value?
- What actions matter to you most?
- What words do you want to hear more?
- What wouldn’t you tolerate?
- What would make you break up?

content.header: 2. How would you show love to your partner?
content.text:
- How would you support them?
- What would you tell them to show affection?
- What actions would express your love?
- What would you never do to them?
- How would you resolve conflict?

Later, you can use your notes to improve your current relationship by talking through things that don’t work for you and expressing gratitude for things that make you feel loved and happy. If you don’t have a partner, these notes will help you form new, healthy bonds as you meet new people.

It's never easy to let go of a toxic attraction, but it's always worth it. The most important thing to remember is that it’s not your fault; it’s your abuser’s fault. There is no reason this has to happen to you; no one deserves to be treated this way. You deserve a healthy, supportive relationship!
We’ve reached the end of today’s session, but we have more in store for you! Join us for Day 5, where we discuss trust, distrust, and the struggles of being open and vulnerable. See you soon!
“You have to learn to get up from the table when love is no longer being served.”
content.title: Nina Simone:

episodes.title: Trust
episodes.description: How to overcome trust issues and build a healthy relationship

content.text: We are so happy that you chose to keep going! So what is today's topic? That’s right, trust.
Do you find it difficult to trust other people? Do you worry ‌they will mistreat you in some way? Do you find yourself feeling isolated, anxious, or even paranoid? If so, you are not alone.

Trust is the foundation of interpersonal relationships. It can make us feel safe, loved, and vulnerable and allow us to give and receive support. Unfortunately, trust issues make it difficult to connect with others or to feel secure in relationships. This can make things like dating, friendships, and even work relationships challenging.
When a child is traumatized, they lose trust in two ways. First, they become afraid of trusting others. Second, their ability to trust themselves is dampened.

Children who experience trauma often don't trust their parents. They learn they cannot rely on them for help or safety. These children have been taught to distrust their parents and others so they won't get hurt or abandoned. This causes them to become adults who struggle to trust others and the world.
In order to trust, you need to have confidence in yourself. Because traumatized children cannot trust themselves, they tend to doubt their own judgment and abilities.
Adam has been dating Frank for almost a year. They get along really well, and Adam is ready to take the next step in their relationship. But there’s a problem; Frank has trust issues.
Throughout their relationship, Adam has found Frank going through his phone, randomly calling his workplace, and even showing up unannounced when Adam goes out with his friends.

content.question: What do you think of their relationship?

explanation.text: Trust is one of the most important things in any relationship; without it, it’s very difficult to build a strong connection with someone.
The good news is that trust is something that can be built! It doesn't happen overnight, but it is possible to develop trust with others.

content.text: Adam loves Frank and cares about him deeply. He wants to help Frank overcome his trust issues but isn’t sure how. Adam needs help in deciding which course of action he should take.

content.question: Do you think Adam should just repeatedly tell Frank, “I trust you” every day?

explanation.text: Showing trust is a very subtle thing. It's not something you can just say.
You can show trust by being honest with others, not lying, not cheating, not being jealous, not being selfish, and not being controlling.
explanation.header: Yes, there are better ways to express trust!

content.text: Adam wants to know why Frank doesn’t fully trust him. In order to understand the root of distrust, Adam wants to understand Frank's past and help him share his experiences with a professional.

content.question: Is talking about childhood a good way to heal wounds and build trust?

answerOptions.text: Only if they suffered severe trauma

explanation.text: A lack of trust can stem from all sorts of experiences, including past betrayals, trauma, or simply never having had a strong foundation of trust to begin with.

answerOptions.text: Yes, try to understand the roots of the issue

explanation.text: There is evidence that points to the fact that childhood trauma causes distrust. Trauma causes a person to distrust the world they were raised in. It is challenging to build trust when you were also not trusted as a child.

content.text: One thing Adam is worried about is control. He wants to reassure Frank that he can be trusted, but he doesn’t want Frank to become controlling.

content.question: Is Adam overreacting?

explanation.text: At times, a lack of trust can drive a person to engage in controlling behavior ‌to mask their insecurity. That’s why setting boundaries and discussing expectations and limitations is crucial.
Some individuals with trust issues are afraid of being taken advantage of, so they desire complete control.

content.text: One quiet night, Adam invited Frank to have an honest chat with him. Adam made sure that Frank didn’t feel pressured to talk about anything he wasn’t ready to discuss. Frank acknowledged the fact that he has difficulty trusting others because of hurtful events in the past. They are both committed to listening to each other and respecting one another’s boundaries. Building trust takes time, but love is patient!

If you were hurt in the past, it's only natural to be wary of trusting again. It can be challenging to let your guard down and give someone else the chance to hurt you, but it is possible! Cast aside the chains of distrust by following our three-step plan based on the three M’s.

Childhood trauma can make it difficult to move on and trust again. Be patient with yourself; it takes time to heal from trauma. Give yourself time to accept and work through your feelings. It’s important to remember that not all people are the same and that you can find people who will treat you well.

Practicing mindfulness is an excellent strategy to help build trust. When you use mindfulness, you become more aware of how you feel in the present moment without worrying about the past or future. Meditation, yoga, or other relaxation techniques can help you feel at peace and less anxious about trusting others. Reconnect with yourself and trust yourself.

Here are five questions you can ask another person to build trust and connect. Do you want to tell me about your relationship with your family? Do you feel comfortable telling me your secrets? What do you think about our relationship? Are you happy with who I am? How would you solve this problem?

Don't be afraid to give people a chance. Just because someone has hurt you in the past doesn't mean everyone will. But when you meet someone new, don't immediately put all your trust in them. Get to know them first and see if they are trustworthy.

If you feel like someone is mistreating you, speak up! If you have a gut feeling that someone is not to be trusted, listen to that instinct and take action accordingly. If you feel safe, communicate your concerns and see if they are willing to work to build trust.
We will give you a trust checklist: a series of questions to ask yourself as you work towards building trust. Let’s take a quick quiz and see how you can improve trust.
New story text
content.question: Are you honest with yourself?

explanation.text: Great! If you're not honest with yourself, it is difficult to trust yourself. Stay honest about your thoughts, fears, motivations, and goals.
If you're not honest with yourself, it is difficult to trust yourself. Be honest about your thoughts, fears, motivations, and goals.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Are you honest with others?

explanation.text: Perfect. If you're honest with others, it is easier to trust them. Stay honest about your feelings, your needs, and your wants.
If you're not honest with others, it is difficult to trust them. Be honest about your feelings, your needs, and your wants.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Are you mindful of your emotions?

explanation.text: You got it! Be aware of what you're thinking and feeling at the moment. You're more likely to trust yourself when you're aware of your thoughts and emotions.
Be aware of what you're thinking and feeling at the moment. You're more likely to trust yourself when you're aware of your thoughts and emotions.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Are you mindful of the emotions of others?

explanation.text: If you're not aware of the emotions of others, it will be difficult to trust them. Pay attention to the way they're acting and what they're saying.
If you're not aware of the emotions of others, it will be difficult to trust them. Pay attention to the way they're acting and what they're saying.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Do you listen to your gut?

explanation.text: If something doesn't feel right, it probably isn't. Trust your instincts and intuition. But still, don't rush decisions. Talk to someone first, cool down, and try to assess the situation mindfully.
If something doesn't feel right, it probably isn't. Trust your instincts and intuition. But still, don't rush decisions. Talk to someone first, cool down, and try to assess the situation mindfully.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Do you talk to someone about your worries?

explanation.text: It’s important to have somebody to talk to. If you bottle up, you are more likely to have difficulties trusting people. Talk to somebody who makes you feel safe: family, friends, partner. You can also text our mental coach, who will help you figure things out.

It’s important to have somebody to talk to. If you bottle up, you are more likely to have difficulties trusting people. Talk to somebody who makes you feel safe: family, friends, partner. You can also text our mental coach, who will help you figure things out.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Do you practice self-care?

explanation.text: If you're not taking care of yourself, it will be difficult to trust yourself. Make sure you get enough sleep, eat healthily, and exercise regularly.
If you're not taking care of yourself, it will be difficult to trust yourself. Make sure you get enough sleep, eat healthily, and exercise regularly.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Are you patient?

explanation.text: Learning to trust again takes time. Don't expect to feel ‌you can trust everyone overnight suddenly. Allow yourself to build up trust over time slowly.
Learning to trust again takes time. Don't expect to feel ‌you can trust everyone overnight suddenly. Allow yourself to build up trust over time slowly.

content.header: Summing Up! Here’s the whole checklist.
content.text:
Take screenshots of each part, so you could get back when you need them.

Part 1. Communicate Effectively
- Be honest with yourself
- Be honest with others
- Communicate openly and honestly

- Be mindful of your emotions
- Be mindful of the emotions of others
- I listen to your gut but don’t rush

- Practice self-care
- Take baby steps
If you have trust issues, it's important to remember that it's not permanent. You can overcome trust issues with time, patience, effort, some soul-searching, and honest self-reflection.

Well, today’s session has come to an end. Next, we’ll talk about a sticky topic: emotions. Tomorrow, we will teach you how you can become better at identifying and authentically expressing your feelings.
“Trust cannot be proven unless a little is given first.”
content.title: Jack Brown:

episodes.title: Expressing Emotions
episodes.description: Why bottling up harms you and how you can work with emotions

content.text: New story text
content.question: Welcome to Day 6!

explanation.text: We all have them. But sometimes, emotions can be difficult to go through. They can be overwhelming and make us feel out of control. However, it is important to remember that emotions are a normal and healthy part of life. They are our way of processing and responding to the world around us.

We all have them. But sometimes, emotions can be difficult to go through. They can be overwhelming and make us feel out of control. However, it is important to remember that emotions are a normal and healthy part of life. They are our way of processing and responding to the world around us.

We all have them. But sometimes, emotions can be difficult to go through. They can be overwhelming and make us feel out of control. However, it is important to remember that emotions are a normal and healthy part of life. They are our way of processing and responding to the world around us.

content.questionFooter: What if you could express your emotions freely, without judgment or worry? How would you feel?

content.text: It's important to remember that everyone deals with their emotions differently, and there is no right or wrong way to do so. However, suppose you find that you're constantly hiding your feelings from others and avoiding any type of emotional connection. In that case, it’s time to access tools and resources for dealing with your emotions in a healthy way.

People hide their feelings for various reasons. Some may feel they need to protect themselves emotionally, while others fear judgment or rejection. Whatever the reason, hiding our emotions can take a toll on our mental and physical health.

Sadness and worry can lead to hiding emotions and the other way round. Sadness can cause us to withdraw from others and stop expressing our feelings. This can make it difficult for friends and family to understand what's going on inside us. Anxiety can also cause us to avoid situations or people that make us uncomfortable, making it hard to form close relationships or resolve conflict.
New story text
content.question: Does Avoidance Help or Hinder?

explanation.text: Long-term avoidance can make things worse by preventing us from dealing with our issues and resolving them.

When we bottle up our emotions instead of dealing with them head-on, we're not giving ourselves a chance to process those feelings and work through them, which can lead to further emotional distress down the road.

content.text: The impact of early life stress on emotions later in life is well known. What is less understood is how to heal from emotional neglect. You can learn how to regulate your emotions and develop healthier coping mechanisms with the right support!

Alice is married to a soft-spoken man named John. They have a peaceful relationship and rarely argue. On the surface, they seem to have the ideal marriage. But Alice is constantly worried. She doesn’t want her true feelings to ruin their relationship.

content.question: This means that Alice

answerOptions.text: Suppresses her negative emotions to avoid conflict

explanation.text: If Alice suppresses her negative emotions, she cannot learn and grow from the conflict. By suppressing her emotions, Alice is avoiding conflict that could be used to improve herself and her relationship.

answerOptions.text: Balances her needs with John’s needs

explanation.text: Alice is ignoring her emotional needs because she believes that if she lets herself express her negative emotions, she will be more likely to argue with John.

content.text: There are things that John does (and doesn’t do) that frustrate Alice. He rarely helps her out with chores, spends most of his time playing computer games, and prefers to stay home instead of going out with Alice. When Alice tries to tell him how she feels, he tells her to “stop being so sensitive!”
New story text
content.question: What is John doing?

explanation.text: When you're constantly being dismissed or invalidated, it can take a toll on your self-esteem and sense of self-worth. You may feel invisible and start to doubt your own experiences and perceptions. Your mental and physical health can also suffer–all of this stress can lead to problems with mental and physical health and sleep issues.

answerOptions.text: John is attempting to prevent a fight

explanation.text: If you're in a relationship with someone who dismisses your emotions, you may feel ‌like your partner never takes your feelings seriously or like they are always trying to invalidate your experience. This can be incredibly frustrating and emotionally exhausting.

content.text: Alice finally had enough. When she came home from work, she found John playing computer games instead of washing the dishes, as he promised. She burst into tears and yelled at John. When John said this phrase, Alice knew something had to change.
New story text
content.question: Which phrase do you think John said?

explanation.text: This is a phrase that Alice needed to hear so that she could let out her emotions. If you bottle up your feelings for too long, you may eventually reach a breaking point where all of your repressed emotion comes flooding out uncontrolled, which can be highly damaging to yourself and those around you.

answerOptions.text: “It’s just a few dishes. No need to get upset.”

explanation.text: This phrase was emotionally dismissive and harmful because it invalidated Alice’s experiences and thoughts. Emotionally dismissive phrases perpetuate the belief that we are not good enough or worthy of having valid feelings. This can lead to a vicious cycle of self-doubt and low self-esteem.

content.text: Alice took her journal and went to a nearby park. She began writing about her childhood and noticed a familiar pattern; her parents were also emotionally dismissive. They would tell her ‌she was a “bad child” when she expressed anger or cried.
New story text
content.question: Alice’s parents

explanation.text: At times, parents do not intentionally dismiss their child’s feelings to cause harm. Often, they just want their child to feel positive emotions, so they will try to distract, cheer up, or invalidate negative feelings, which leads the child to suppress their emotions.

answerOptions.text: Didn’t know how to deal with negative emotions

explanation.text: Some parents believe that if they don’t acknowledge a negative emotion, it will go away. They may lack the language or the skills to help their children healthily express emotions.

content.text: When Alice returned home, the house was spotless! John invited her to sit and have an open conversation with him. They talked about the challenges in their relationship and how they can overcome them together. As a result, John started doing more chores, playing fewer games, and even starting a new hobby with Alice! With some help, Alice finally learned how to express her emotions.

When you dismiss your emotions, you may become disconnected from others and have difficulty forming meaningful relationships. Reconnect and regulate your emotions through our three-step program based on the three M’s.

The first step is simple but challenging: acknowledge your feelings. Write ‌your thoughts in a journal or on a blog. Writing can help you process your emotions so that you may understand them better and find solutions to the problems that are causing them. It’s also a way to release emotions, so they are not bottled up inside you.

When practicing mindfulness, it is vital to be aware of what you feel, physically and emotionally. Start by paying attention to your body; what physical sensations are you experiencing? Then listen to your thoughts; what are you thinking about? Once you have identified your thoughts and emotions, you can begin to process them.

Exercise is a great way to release emotions. It can help you feel better both physically and mentally. Physical activity can help to release tension and to boost your mood. Try to spend time outside in nature and take in the surrounding beauty. This helps you feel more connected to the world and reduces stress and worry. Also, expressing your emotions through art, music, writing, or any other creative outlet can be very therapeutic.

If you’re struggling to express your emotions, talking to someone can be helpful. This could be a friend, family member, or anyone you feel comfortable talking to. After today's session, you can also text our mental coach to understand your emotions better and make them more manageable!

This time, let’s try to focus on your emotions. We want you to practice identifying your emotions to better understand and express them. Take a pen and a piece of paper, and we'll give you some journaling prompts!
Think about the emotions you felt throughout the day. Jot down positive and negative ones. The wheel above can help you label them!
Under the positive label, write what brought you happiness, joy, and pleasure. Under the negative label, write what brought up feelings of negativity.
Now that you have your list of positive and negative emotions and experiences, we want you to do these three things.

Whatever method you choose to express your emotions, it is important to do so in a way that is healthy for you. Remember, it is okay to feel all of your emotions, even the negative ones. The key is finding healthy ways to express them, so they do not become overwhelming.
That’s it for today’s discussion! But we’re not finished yet. Even though our love for you is boundless, we will discuss boundaries in our upcoming session. We look forward to seeing you there!
“Feelings come and go like clouds in the sky. Conscious breathing is my anchor.”
content.title: Thich Nhat Hanh:

episodes.title: Boundaries
episodes.description: Realize your own true value and empower yourself

content.text: This session discusses why boundaries are important and how to set and maintain them.

Boundaries are the limits we set on how much time, energy, and emotional investment we give to others. They help us ‌maintain our individuality and personal space while still being able to relate to others. When our boundaries are healthy, they allow us to have positive relationships with others without feeling overwhelmed or drained.
Let’s take a quick quiz.
New story text
content.question: Do you find it difficult to say "no" to people?

explanation.text: We’re going to work on it!
Great!

content.text: New story text
content.question: Do you frequently put other people's needs above your own?

explanation.text: Remember, it’s not selfish to make yourself and your mental health a priority!
You’ve got it!

content.text: New story text
content.question: Do you find it hard to stick up for yourself?

explanation.text: Yeah, it might be so difficult at times! We’ll help you learn how to stand your ground.
Nice!

content.text: New story text
content.question: Are you constantly making excuses for other people's bad behavior?

explanation.text: Note, someone's crappy behavior does not mean you have to accept it!
Keep going!

content.text: New story text
content.question: Do people often take advantage of your generosity or kindness?

explanation.text: No worries, we’ve got the tools that can help you!
Awesome!

content.text: If you answered yes to any of those questions, you might need to work on your boundaries. Today’s practice will help you set your boundaries straight, prioritize your needs and feelings and stop other people from taking advantage. So stick till the end!

Childhood trauma can have a lasting impact on self-esteem, relationships, and overall mental and physical health. But it is possible to heal from early life traumas and establish healthy boundaries later in life.

Boundaries play a significant role in helping those who have experienced childhood trauma heal and move forward. How?
1) Establishing healthy boundaries can help people feel more secure and empowered
2) Boundaries can help protect against further hurt and allow healing to take place

If you're struggling with establishing appropriate limits in your relationships, there are fortunately many things you can do to start building healthier boundaries. With a bit of effort and practice, setting solid boundaries can become second nature!

content.header: Alfred is Here To Say Hi!
content.text: Meet Alfred. He is a single adult with many friends and a busy work life. Lately, he’s been feeling physically and emotionally drained. He has a hard time saying “no” but isn’t sure why.
New story text
content.question: What type of environment do you think Alfred grew up in?

explanation.text: It is possible that healthy boundary-setting was not modeled or encouraged in Alfred’s family. But the opposite is also true.
Alfred grew up in a family where rigid borders were enforced, which led him to believe that any kind of boundary is bad.

content.text: Growing up, Alfred had to follow the rules of his household, or he would be punished. If Alfred spilled a glass of milk or accidentally got his clothes dirty, he would be told how clumsy and worthless he was.
New story text
content.question: How do you think his traumatic childhood affected his boundaries as an adult?

explanation.text: Simply having low self-esteem can contribute to setting weaker than necessary limits with others because you have difficulty standing up for yourself.
Allowing other people's behavior and emotions to control how you feel about yourself instead of basing it on your own worthiness as an individual is a sign of weak boundaries.

content.text: Recently, Alfred has been caught in a cycle of frustration. His boss keeps overloading him with work, and his friends push him to drink more alcohol. Alfred ends up accepting drink after drink from his friends and report after report from his boss.
New story text
content.question: What will happen if Alfred continues down this path?

explanation.text: Feeling overloaded and stressed out from trying to meet everyone else's needs while neglecting your own can lead to all of these problems

explanation.header: Unfortunately, all of thoseUnfortunately, all of those
explanation.text: Feeling overloaded and stressed out from trying to meet everyone else's needs while neglecting your own can lead to all of these problems
Feeling overloaded and stressed out from trying to meet everyone else's needs while neglecting your own can lead to all of these problems
Feeling overloaded and stressed out from trying to meet everyone else's needs while neglecting your own can lead to all of these problems
Feeling overloaded and stressed out from trying to meet everyone else's needs while neglecting your own can lead to all of these problems
Feeling overloaded and stressed out from trying to meet everyone else's needs while neglecting your own can lead to all of these problems

content.text: On weekends, Alfred has a full schedule. His parents call him early Saturday mornings and tell him to come run errands for them. Alfred doesn’t want to disappoint his parents, so he spends all his free time doing as they say.
New story text
content.question: Is Alfred an outstanding son, or does he lack boundaries?

explanation.text: An excellent way to tell if your boundaries are weak is by looking at how much you allow others to control or dictate your life.

If you frequently let others decide for you, then it is time to set firm boundaries. Alfred struggles with maintaining healthy relationships. He’s constantly giving or withdrawing too much because he tries unsuccessfully to please everyone.

content.text: One day, Alfred downloaded a mental health app. He took a quiz and answered “yes” to ‌these questions. Do I let people take advantage of me? Do I find myself in relationships or situations that are harmful or toxic? Do I have a hard time saying "no" to requests? Do I allow others to control or dictate my emotions? Do I frequently sacrifice my own needs for the sake of others?

Alfred quickly realized that he needed to make a significant change. He began reading articles and books about setting boundaries. Alfred can now balance his work, social, and family life because he learned how to say “no.” Now he also has plenty of free time to reflect and do things that make him happy!

Setting healthy boundaries is an essential part of taking care of yourself and maintaining your well-being. This means setting limits on what you will and will not tolerate from others. It also includes taking care of yourself emotionally and physically.

Our three-step plan, based on the three M’s, includes getting clear about what you want and need from others, communicating those expectations clearly and directly, saying "no" more often, and learning how to set firm but compassionate limits. Let’s begin!

Strong boundaries are essential for maintaining healthy relationships with ourselves and others. If you lacked firm boundaries in the past, you might have felt overwhelmed and taken advantage of. Acknowledge the resentment, worry, and sadness you felt due to it.

Find a quiet spot to think and reflect. Now bring out your journal; it’s time to define your wants and needs. What do you want and need from others? What makes you feel comfortable and respected? What are your deal-breakers? Once you know what you need, you can start to set boundaries.

It's important to communicate your boundaries to others. This way, they know what you expect from them and can avoid crossing any lines. Be assertive and direct when you're setting boundaries. Say what you mean, and don't let anyone convince you to lower your standards, even if that means saying "no" or walking away from a situation.

Practice saying these phrases. I wish I could, but I can’t. I’m flattered, but no, thank you. I’m afraid I’m unable to. Unfortunately, I have other plans. I’ve already committed to something else. Whichever phrase you choose, keep in mind that “no” is a complete sentence! You do not owe anyone an explanation.
Let’s start setting boundaries in practice! To do that, you’d need to identify: what you value, what you need for it, and what action you will take. Look at the example above!
You value your me-time and want to reconnect with yourself. But your phone keeps sending notifications that drive you crazy! New messages, reminders, news, the list goes on and on.
New story text
content.question: What can you do about it?

answerOptions.text: Answer everyone, then try to have a rest

explanation.text: If you don’t start prioritizing your needs first, you might find yourself texting people until you have no time for yourself.
This is an excellent choice! If it’s not really urgent, other people and everything else can wait while you have a rest you deserve.
If these notifications keep distracting you, you’ll most likely not get a proper rest.

content.text: Take a pen and a piece of paper! Try to identify what you value, what you need for it, and what action you will take to make yourself a priority. Remember, your wellbeing comes first!

You can't control how others feel, so don't take responsibility for their reactions to your boundaries. They may not be happy about it at first, but it's not your job to make them happy. It’s your job to make you happy!
This was enlightening, wasn’t it? There’s more illuminating information coming up in our next episode, where we talk about self-acceptance. We are waiting for you there!
“Daring to set boundaries is about having the courage to love ourselves, even if we risk disappointing others.”
content.title: Brene Brown:

episodes.title: Self-image
episodes.description: How to love yourself inside and out

content.text: Hello! Today, we will work on getting rid of negative thoughts and feelings about our appearance!

Your appearance is one of the first things people notice about you. It is natural to want to look your best, but it is also important to accept your appearance as it is. You can do many things to increase your self-esteem, and we can help you feel better about yourself!

Self-esteem is how you feel about yourself. It’s the opinion you have of yourself and whether you think you’re worthy of love and respect. People with healthy self-esteem feel good about themselves and feel confident in their ability to handle whatever life throws their way. On the other hand, people with low self-esteem may doubt their abilities and feel unworthy of good things in life.

Childhood trauma can have a devastating effect on self-esteem. Victims of abuse, neglect, or even judgment often struggle with low self-worth and a lack of self-confidence. Any traumatic experience can lead to this. Ultimately, trauma will distort how they view themselves.

If you experienced childhood trauma, you might have internalized the message that you are somehow responsible for the bad things that happened to you. Or you may have come to believe you are not worthy of love and respect. As a result, you may find it difficult to trust people, feel confident in yourself, or feel good about your accomplishments. The good news is that it is possible to heal from childhood trauma and improve your self-esteem!

From a young age, Megan knew she was different. Her clothes had holes, her shoes were always too big or small, and she often had to borrow supplies from classmates. As a result, Megan was bullied for being poor.
New story text
content.question: Do you think the trauma from bullying affected her?

explanation.text: Childhood trauma can cause us to see ourselves negatively. We may doubt our worth and feel like we're not good enough.
Megan has trouble trusting others and difficulty forming close relationships, resulting in isolation and loneliness. All these negatively affect her self-esteem.

content.text: Megan had a hard time forming relationships with others. Because of her low self-esteem and loneliness, she was willing to do anything to make people happy. Despite her hard work and efforts, people constantly criticized her and took advantage of her.
New story text
content.question: What should she do about her personal and professional relationships?

answerOptions.text: Avoid people as often as possible

explanation.text: Avoid people who are critical of you or make you feel bad about yourself. Being around negative people will impact your self-confidence.
It’s important to surround yourself with positive people. Spend time with people who make you feel good about yourself and support your decisions.

content.text: Megan’s boss criticized and scolded her at work, and her friends won’t stop asking her for favors. She arrived home in tears. Out of frustration, she threw an old box of her belongings across the room. A sketchpad and a few tubes of paint tumbled out. Megan was a gifted artist who loved to paint, but her insecurities made her stop painting and hide her talents away.

Megan stopped responding to work emails and text messages. Instead, she turned on her favorite music and started painting again. When Megan painted, she was transported to a different world. In this world, she was free from trauma; her appearance didn’t matter, and she was accepted for who she was.
New story text
content.question: Do you think painting can help Megan gain self-confidence?

answerOptions.text: It won’t help her in the long-term

explanation.text: Engage in activities that make you feel good about yourself. Doing things that make you feel competent, capable, and valued can help boost your self-esteem.

answerOptions.text: It will help her in the long-term

explanation.text: Do something that brings you joy. This can help you start to see yourself in a more positive light by reminding you of your worth.

content.text: We want to encourage you to look beyond what you see in the mirror. Your appearance is only a tiny fraction of who you are. Help heal that wounded child you see in your reflection by following our three-step program, based on the three M’s.

It's important to acknowledge the effect that trauma has had on your life. This can be a difficult but necessary step in the healing process, so practice self-compassion. Be gentle and understanding with yourself. Recognize that you’re doing the best you can and deserve to be treated with kindness and compassion.

Start by identifying the negative thoughts and beliefs you have about yourself. Once you're aware of the ways you're putting yourself down, you can start to challenge and reframe those thoughts. Recognize your strengths and accomplishments, no matter how big or small.

Try to focus on the things you do like about yourself. It can be helpful to write them down and refer to them when you are feeling down about your appearance. Maybe you have great eyes or a fabulous smile. Perhaps you have great hair or nice skin. This will help you appreciate your appearance more.

Stand in front of a mirror and repeat these affirmations as many times as needed. I am worthy. I am loved. I am powerful. I am hardworking. I am kind. I am talented. I deserve respect. I let go of negativity. I am brave, beautiful, and brilliant. I accept myself as I am.

Build a support system of friends, family, or counselors who can help you see yourself in a more positive light. Always remember that everyone is different, which makes us special. We all have different features that make us unique and beautiful. It is important to remember that when you are looking in the mirror.

It can be hard to love yourself when society tells us ‌we need to look a certain way in order to be considered attractive. You can learn to appreciate your looks, regardless of what anyone else says, by completing this task! Strengthen self-love by writing a series of seven compliments. We will provide seven prompts to help guide your journaling.

Write a compliment about a unique feature you have. Acknowledge your unique beauty. Every single person on this planet is beautiful in their own way. Remind yourself of this by looking in the mirror and saying aloud, "I am beautiful." Say it until you believe it!

Write a compliment about your self-worth. Talk back to your inner critic. Whenever negative thoughts creep in, counter them with kinder statements. For example, if you’re thinking, “I’m so unattractive,” try telling yourself, “I am worthy of love and respect just as I am.”

Write a compliment about your body. Surround yourself with positive messages. Fill your social media feeds and bedroom walls with images and words that make you feel good about yourself. Unfollow anyone who makes you feel bad about your body and remember that “all bodies deserve to be celebrated.”

Write a compliment that features kind words. Be mindful of the language you use. The way we talk about our bodies impacts how we feel about them. Make an effort to avoid using words like “hate,” “ugly,” or “disgusting” when referring to your appearance. Instead, focus on words like “strong,” “beautiful,” and “valid.”

Write a compliment about your clothing. Dress for YOU. So often, we get caught up in trends or worry about what others will think of our outfit choices. But at the end of the day, fashion should be fun! Wear whatever makes YOU happy and feels good in YOUR skin–no one else's opinion matters! Yell out, “I look amazing in this outfit!”

Write a compliment about something you do well. Self-care is crucial to self-love. Dedicate some time each week (even if it's just  minutes) to do something that makes you feel good – whether that's painting your nails, going for a walk outside, taking a relaxing bath, or whatever brings joy into your life! Say, “I deserve to be cared for and loved.”

Write a compliment about your smile. Smile often! Smiling not only makes you look more attractive, but it also has the power to boost your mood and increase self-esteem levels. So go ahead and flash those pearly whites as much as possible! Look in the mirror as you smile and say, “My smile is super bright!”

Taking care of your health, both physical and mental, is crucial. So, make sure that you are taking care of yourself in all ways. This includes eating healthy, exercising, getting enough sleep, and taking care of your mental health. When you take care of yourself in all ways, you will be happier and healthier. And that is what is truly important!
Self-love is genuinely the purest love out there. We aren’t ready to let you go just yet. So please join us next time as we sum up the course experience together. Ready? Let’s go!
“You yourself, as much as anybody in the entire universe, deserve your love and affection”
content.title: Buddha:

episodes.title: Reflection
episodes.description: Summing up what we've learned and moving on

content.text: Hello! As you know, this is our final session together, so let’s take some time to reflect on what we've learned.
Over the past few days, we've covered a lot of ground! We've learned about different aspects of childhood trauma, healthy versus unhealthy coping mechanisms, and ways to heal inner wounds.
For our opening session, we featured the link between childhood trauma and adult behavior. We also introduced you to our three-step program based on the three M’s.
New story text
content.question: Do you remember what the three M’s are?

explanation.text: Meditation is a part of mindfulness, and Me-time can help you reconnect with your inner feelings. Our three M’s are, however: Meeting the Past, Mindfulness, Moving on.

answerOptions.text: Moving on, Meeting the Past, Mindfulness

explanation.text: Meditation is a part of mindfulness, and Me-time can help you reconnect with your inner feelings. Our three M’s are, however: Meeting the Past, Mindfulness, Moving on.

answerOptions.text: Meeting the Past, Me-time, Moving on
