Do it while lying down on a bed. Clench your hands into fists and slowly release the tension. Repeat several times. Try to do this with all your muscles, starting from your toes, legs, lower back, and stomach, and moving on to your hands, upper back, and jaw.

It can be incredibly helpful to share your experiences with others who are also suffering from anxiety. Support groups are a great way to do this. These groups are made up of people who have similar problems and offer each other support, advice, and encouragement. They’re free, and you can join online or in person.

Get support from family members or friends, but consider talking to a counselor as well. This is especially important if you don’t feel that your loved ones are supporting you enough during this difficult time. A counselor will help ensure your conversations are productive and not harmful.
I know what you're thinking: if I could just get rid of my anxiety, everything would be great. But the truth is that we have to learn how to live with our anxiety, not just avoid it.

It's true that there are lots of ways you can try to manage your anxiety (and some of them might work for you). But the best thing to do is find a combination of different strategies. One day you might go for a run or listen to music, and another day you'll take a yoga class or meet with a therapist.

The important thing is that you know what works for YOU. So just keep trying different things until something works for you—and then keep doing that until it doesn't work anymore. Then try something else!

Well, friends, today has come to an end. Join us next time as we address two annoying little things we carry deep in our hearts. They bypass our minds and communicate directly with us. We’re talking about regret and guilt. See you there!
When you change the way you look at things, the things you look at change.
content.title: Dr. Wayne Dyer

episodes.title: Avoid unproductive guilt trips
episodes.description: How to get out of the guilt and regret spiral

content.text: No one is immune to guilt and regret. Emotions are part of our being and these two emotions in particular strike us when we do something wrong (be it knowingly or unknowingly). It may feel like a black cloud looming over you. If you're feeling this way, take a walk with us. We’ll help you remove the clouds, water the grass, and revitalize your inner self.

Regret creeps into your life when you start thinking about all the things you want to change and fear not having enough time to do them. For example, regret will set in if you want to lose weight but can’t find the time or motivation. You might wish that you had been more consistent with your diet and exercise program so that you could see results faster.

Guilt can take over when you feel you've let someone down or missed an opportunity. It can also result from something you've done that you think is wrong or not in line with your values. For example, you might feel guilty about not visiting a sick relative, or you could regret not asking for a pay rise.

Guilt and regret are emotional responses to our past actions that can hold us back from being who we want in the future. Many of us have felt guilty or regretful at some point in our lives, but what exactly is the difference between those emotions? And why do we feel them?

Guilt and regret are similar but different. Guilt is feeling bad about something you've done (or not done), whereas regret is sadness over what has happened in the past and cannot be changed. For example, I feel guilty when I stay up late on the computer, but I regret it because it makes me tired in the morning.
Imagine this scenario: you got your ex-lover's name tattooed.
New story text
content.question: You likely feel:

explanation.text: Guilt is the feeling that you have jeopardized your own or another person’s well-being.
Regret is a sense of sadness, disappointment, or sorrow over something that has happened or been done.

content.text: Let’s try another scenario: you accidentally hit a car while backing out of a parking spot.
New story text
content.question: You likely feel:

explanation.text: Guilt is the feeling we get when we've done something that harmed something, another person, or ourselves.
Regret is the emotion we feel when we have made a decision that turned out badly for us.

content.header: Why do we feel guilt and regret?
content.text: Why do we feel bad about things beyond our control? It’s a question that has plagued philosophers for centuries and seems to be the topic of discussion at every dinner party! But now scientists have come up with an answer: it’s all about evolution.

Our brains have evolved to feel bad about behaviors that might make us vulnerable to attack from other people – like overeating or being selfish. This is called "aversive emotion," and it leads us to avoid these actions in the future.
New story text
content.question: Test yourself! Why would your brain make you feel guilty about lying to your friend?

explanation.text: Our brain makes us feel bad when we misbehave to discourage us from repeating bad behavior in the future.
If you feel guilty about lying, you might think twice before lying again.

content.text: When we dwell on past mistakes, we become trapped in them. We think about how we could have done things differently and how our lives would be different. If you're constantly worrying about things that have already happened, you're not going to be able to focus on what's happening right now.

The problem with this type of thinking is that it keeps us from moving forward in life. It keeps us stuck in the past and prevents us from seeing the possibilities in front of us today. Just ask Gary.

In his teenage years, Gary made a mistake. He ran a stop sign and hit another car. It was entirely his fault, and the other driver was injured. His parents had to spend their life savings covering those expenses because they were uninsured. Gary was left with a terrible sense of guilt and regret.

His life was stuck in a holding pattern. Gary couldn't enjoy the present because he was always thinking about the past. This made it difficult for him to move forward in life, as well; his guilt and regret weighed too heavily upon his mind. But one day, while sitting in the park, his life changed.

He saw a bird sitting on a branch. It was so beautiful—but then he noticed that one of the bird's legs was broken, and it couldn't fly away from the tree. The bird was stuck in the same way that he was.
New story text
content.question: That means Gary

explanation.text: Because of his guilt and regret, Gary feels like he is stuck in one place, like the bird.

answerOptions.text: Is immobilized by guilt and regret.

explanation.text: Because he feels guilty and regrets his actions, Gary has been unable to fulfill his dreams.

content.text: The bird wasn't able to fly away from its troubles, just like Gary couldn't move forward in his life because of too much guilt and regret. But then something spectacular happened. A small boy came along and started feeding the bird some bread crumbs.

The bird began to sing as the little boy continued to feed him. The boy kept feeding him, and the bird started flying around and singing even louder than before. This made Gary smile—he hadn't been able to do that in a long time.

content.header: Gary wants to sing and fly
content.text: Finally, the little boy walked away from the tree. When he was gone, the bird stopped singing and flew away into the sky. Gary realized he had been feeding his own emotions on a loop for years—feeding them with negative thoughts about himself and other people in his life.
“I regret what happened, but that doesn’t mean it defines me or my character.”
New story text
content.question: Is this a positive thought?

explanation.text: It shows that you have not only learned from the past but also have taken steps to ensure that it does not happen again.
This thought is about taking responsibility and forgiving yourself.

content.text: Gary decided he would spend more time feeding his happiness and less time feeding his pain. He wanted to focus on the good things in life instead of dwelling on all the bad. He knew that if he could do this, his life would start looking up again.
New story text
content.question: True or false? You’re always thinking about what you could have done differently and beating yourself up over past mistakes.

explanation.header: You might be living in regret and guilt, but you can still turn things around.
explanation.text: Take some time to think about what you want from life, then go get it!

explanation.header: You’re doing okay, but there’s room for improvement.
explanation.text: Try to be more proactive about your future, and always keep your eye on the prize!

explanation.header: Your life is going pretty well!
explanation.text: Keep working on yourself, and don’t forget to enjoy the journey.

content.text: To move forward in life, you need to start thinking about where you want to go instead of always looking back at where you've been. How? Well, we’ve got you covered! Follow our five-step plan to fight the unrelenting feelings of guilt and regret. Let’s get going.

The first step is acknowledging that you feel guilty and regretful. Acknowledge that these feelings are valid and real. Don’t try to deny them or pretend they are not there. This can be difficult, but facing your emotions head-on is essential.

When you feel guilty or regretful, ask yourself what exactly is making you feel that way. Is it because someone was harmed in some way? Or is it because something happened that shouldn't have happened?
New story text
content.question: Good vs bad guilt. If you feel guilty because your words hurt someone, that’s a

explanation.text: It means you care about other people and want to avoid hurting them in the future.
Guilt is good when it prevents people from repeating destructive behaviors.

content.text: Once you've acknowledged your feelings and understood the root, start to work on forgiving yourself. This doesn't mean forgetting what happened or condoning your actions; it simply means accepting that the past is in the past and letting go of the negative feelings associated with it. Say the following affirmations every day will help.

• I forgive myself for all my mistakes and failures. 
• I take credit for my successes and learn from my failures.
• I know that if I make mistakes, there is no need to dwell on them because they are a part of learning. 
• I have learned from this experience and will do better next time. 
• Mistakes don't diminish my worth as a person; they help me grow.
• I will not let regret dictate my actions or decisions.

Once you've forgiven yourself, it's time to work on making peace with the people you may have wronged in the past. Make a list of everyone you've hurt in the past, and write down what you did to cause each person pain. If there are extenuating circumstances that might explain your actions, describe them.

If you think you could do things differently, write how you would have handled things differently in hindsight. Finally, ask yourself if it's possible to reach out to each person on this list and apologize for what you've done wrong. If so, write a plan of action for how you will do so.

Acknowledging and accepting responsibility for your actions is an important first step to learning how to manage feelings of guilt, but it's also crucial to let go of anger toward yourself. By practicing self-compassion, you can begin to heal from past mistakes.

Self-compassion is the act of treating yourself with kindness, care, and understanding in the face of suffering. It’s about making space for both your failures and your successes. It's not about denying or hiding your feelings. It's just being honest with yourself and allowing yourself to feel whatever comes up—joy, sadness, frustration, or anything else.

Start practicing self-compassion right away by writing some important things to YOU—maybe it's having a healthy diet, getting enough exercise, or spending time with friends. Then ask yourself: What would I say to someone who wants to do the same thing? Would I be supportive? Would I offer encouragement? If so, try saying those things to yourself.
You have trouble staying on track with your exercise routine, so you feel regret.
New story text
content.question: Which statement is NOT centered on self-compassion?

explanation.text: This statement is NOT self-compassionate. Self-compassion is a powerful tool. It reduces anxiety and depression by helping you see the positive side of adverse events in your life.

answerOptions.text: "I'm proud of how hard you've been trying."

explanation.text: This statement IS centered on self-compassion. It is good for your mental health.
This one is a self-compassionate statement. Talking to yourself this way makes it easier to achieve goals and improve performance.

answerOptions.text: "I know it's tough right now, but don't give up!"

explanation.text: This is a great example of self-compassion. Did you know that treating yourself with kindness increases happiness and well-being in relationships?

content.header: Learning to live with guilt and regret
content.text: We are all naturally hardwired to feel guilt or regret about anything we do that is outside of our norm or routine. But don't be pulled too far down into that negativity vortex! Spend more time thinking about what you can and will do next, rather than lamenting what didn't happen or making excuses for your past mistakes.

Day 4 has ended. But have you ever heard the expression, “seeing red”? It means to become angry. Many people associate anger—with its hot and burning colors—to high blood pressure and a racing heart rate because these are symptoms of this emotion. We have much more to say about this topic so tune in next time! See you there!
Nobody can go back and start a new beginning, but anyone can start today and make a new ending.
content.title: Maria Robinson

episodes.title: Stop anger from taking over
episodes.description: Why we get angry and what can we do about it

content.text: Welcome back! You feel a lump in your throat, tightness in the stomach or chest, and an urge to hit something. What might you feel when someone you care about breaks a promise they’ve made to you or when ‌you've been deceived? Anger.

Anger is an emotion that everyone experiences. It’s usually provoked by another emotion (anxiety, fear, hurt, disappointment, etc). For example, if a child is afraid of the dark and their parents don't come to comfort them, that might make the child feel angry at their parents for not being there when they needed it.

Generally speaking, there are four main causes of anger: frustration, feeling overwhelmed or powerless, feeling threatened or hurt, and injustice. We all experience these feelings from time to time, and we may react with anger. But for some people, these feelings are more intense and frequent than others. Why is that?

It’s because of a combination of factors, including the way our brains are wired and the experiences we have in life. Some people are more prone to anger than others; it's not simply a matter of willpower or having good self-control.
New story text
content.question: What happens when we hold on to our anger?

explanation.header: It does, but it’s not the only effect of anger.
explanation.text: When we hold on to our anger, it can become toxic—leading us down a path of mental health issues like stress and anxiety. Physically, high blood pressure is triggered by feelings of anger.

explanation.header: It does, but it’s not the only effect of anger.
explanation.text: When we hold on to our anger, it can become toxic—leading us down a path of mental health issues like stress and anxiety. Physically, high blood pressure is triggered by feelings of anger.

explanation.header: It does, but it’s not the only effect of anger.
explanation.text: Physically, high blood pressure is triggered by feelings of anger. When we hold on to our anger, it can also become toxic—leading us down a path of mental health issues like stress and anxiety.

answerOptions.text: All of the options are correct.

explanation.text: Holding on to anger is not a good strategy. It becomes toxic, causes more stress and anxiety. Physically, high blood pressure is triggered by feelings of anger.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Can anger be beneficial?

explanation.header: Exactly! And you can use it.
explanation.text: Anger can be a positive emotion if you use it to stand up for yourself and others. It makes you feel confident by giving you the strength to fight for what's right. You can use anger to motivate yourself to achieve your goals. It’s important to know when it’s appropriate to be angry and when it's not.

explanation.header: Turns out, it can! And you can use it.
explanation.text: Anger can be a positive emotion if you use it to stand up for yourself and others. It makes you feel confident by giving you the strength to fight for what's right. You can use anger to motivate yourself to achieve your goals. It’s important to know when it’s appropriate to be angry and when it's not.

content.text: Here’s an example: you might become angry at your boss for criticizing you in front of the entire office. This motivates you to work harder and prove them wrong. Harness the benefits of anger by learning how to manage it effectively, just like Fred and Fatima.
Fatima and Fred were classmates at a university. They took the same introductory psychology class but had very different reactions to one of its topics—anger.

Fred was a hothead; he got angry about small things like forgetting his keys or having his car break down—then took it out on whoever happened to be nearby. It just seemed like something would set him off without warning, and then he wouldn't be able to stop himself from exploding into a rage.

Fatima has been practicing anger management techniques since she was young. She had trained herself over the years to breathe deeply when she felt angry or count to ten before responding to people who upset her.
New story text
content.question: Which is NOT a reason Fred and Fatima respond to anger differently?

explanation.text: Turns out, some people have brains that are more sensitive to negative emotions than others. An almond-shaped part of the brain called the amygdala helps us process emotion. If it is highly reactive, a person will probably experience anger more often with greater intensity.
Anger is rooted in many factors, including childhood experiences and cultural norms.
People who feel anxious and depressed, or have an underlying emotional problem, are more likely to experience anger.
Love has the power to overcome anger by providing us with a positive outlook on life.

content.text: The two classmates were working together on an assignment for their psychology class. Fred was frustrated that he couldn't figure out how to answer a question, and Fatima kept interrupting him with comments like "Hey, look at this!" or "Did you know that?" Fred felt anger bubbling up inside him. Then he lost control.

"Stop it!" he shouted, slamming his hand down on the table. "You're only making things worse!" Fred was so embarrassed. He didn't mean to yell at Fatima like that—he was just so frustrated by the situation. Fred apologized and left.

Fatima said in class the next day, "I know it's hard to control your emotions. Feeling angry is OK, but you can't let it get the best of you." Fred thought about this for a while and decided that he could choose how he handled his anger.

Fred started practicing Fatima's way of controlling anger. The next time he felt angry, he took a deep breath and counted to ten before reacting—something that got him praise from Fatima when she noticed what was happening. "You're learning how to manage your emotions!" she said proudly.
Fred is on the right path! However, focusing on how we act when angry is only part of the solution. It's also important to address what makes us feel this way in the first place. Let’s get started!
Anger can manifest itself in many different ways: from annoyance to fury. It's helpful to look for the source of your anger - perhaps another feeling was hidden underneath.

Let's say you're a parent and your child spills juice on the carpet; you might feel angry. You may also feel guilty for losing your temper. You might also feel sad about cleaning the mess or frustrated that you have to do so much work around the house. Identifying your feelings will help you determine what caused your anger and how to process it effectively.

Once you've identified the source of your anger, it's important to address and process it—that is, understand where the feeling came from to find constructive ways of dealing with whatever situation made you angry. Here's how.

Find a pen and paper and a quiet place to sit. Then, write about a situation that made you angry. We’ve prepared five questions to help you dig below the surface and identify the root of your anger. You can do this!

1) What made you feel angry? (For example, a friend canceled on you at the last minute.) 
2) When did it happen? (If possible, write the date and time.) 
3) How did it make you feel? (For example, frustrated, annoyed, disappointed?)

4) Why did you feel the way you did? Were there any external factors at play here? (Maybe you felt frustrated because this has happened before.)  
5) What do you need to do differently in the future? (For example, talk to your friend about this issue and see if there's anything that can be done.)

Once you have processed the anger and can recognize what triggers it, it's time to learn how to manage your feelings when something upsetting happens. Here are three steps you can take to build good habits today.

To help you calm down when you're upset, take a few deep breaths and count to ten before responding to someone or something that upsets you. Saying something soothing like "it's okay" or "I'm okay" can also help calm yourself—this will allow your brain time to think more clearly and choose the right words.

When your blood pressure rises, take a walk around the block, do some stretching exercises (such as neck rolls), or run through your favorite relaxation techniques. Then approach the subject with gentleness rather than malice or harshness. If you're feeling angry, take a moment to pause and collect yourself before speaking.

Don’t repress your emotions. Instead, discuss them with someone capable of giving you an objective opinion (not a friend or family member involved in the situation). If you're not in the mood for a full-blown heart-to-heart, jot down your feelings on paper instead. Here are five fun ways to let it out!
Write down what you are angry about and then rip it up. This is a safe way to express your anger without causing yourself or others harm.
Do something nice for someone else. Anger often causes us to focus on the wrong things, and when we channel anger into charitable acts, it makes us appreciate others more.
Laugh—it’s good medicine! Laughing is a wonderful method for relieving stress and anxiety, two factors that can lead to anger.
Take a cold shower or bath. This form of relaxation also helps reduce stress and lower blood pressure.
Eat dark chocolate—it’s good for your heart! Eating chocolate can boost serotonin levels in our brains, which makes us feel happier.
When you begin to feel angry, ask yourself if the situation will matter in five years. If not—and most things don't—you should let go of your anger and move on with life.

Anger isn't a feeling to be feared or dreaded; instead, we all need to learn how to deal with it. If you recognize the emotion, know what is causing it, and take steps to overcome it, you'll be able to control your reactions better. The power really is in our hands!

Have you ever felt like your mind was racing and that there were too many thoughts in it? Like you were drowning in those thoughts? If so, then perhaps what you experienced was a case of overthinking. Join us next time as we discuss how to get out of your head and back into the world around you. See you there!
You gather more flowers with an open hand than a closed fist.
content.title: Zen Adage

episodes.title: Overcome the overthinker's mindset
episodes.description: How to get out of your head and into action

content.text: Imagine you’ve met someone and got their phone number. “Should I send them a text? What if they don’t reply? What if there is no spark and we have nothing in common? Should I wait for them to make the first move? What if they think of me as desperate or stalker-ish?”. Overthinking may have played a role in this scenario.

Perhaps you've noticed that it's often hard to make decisions, even when they seem simple and obvious. If you're an overthinker, it may be because your brain is constantly trying to predict what could go wrong with each choice or putting too much emphasis on the potential outcomes.

Overthinking can lead to indecisiveness and procrastination—and sometimes even paralysis by analysis! It can also cause stress and anxiety about making decisions. Don't worry; we're here to help you overcome overthinking so you can take action without agonizing over every decision.
If you answer yes to two or more of the following questions, chances are good that your thinking style has some strong elements of overthinking.
New story text
content.question: 1. Do you relive embarrassing moments in your mind over and over?

explanation.text: It’s pretty normal to replay embarrassing moments in your mind, but it can be a problem if it always happens.
You don't linger on embarrassing moments from your past. That's great!

content.text: New story text
content.question: 2. Do you ruminate about how your life could have been better if you had done things differently?

explanation.text: If you constantly dwell on past events, moving forward with your life is hard.
It's good that you accept the things in life that cannot be changed.

content.text: New story text
content.question: 3. Do you second guess your decisions?

explanation.text: When you second guess your decisions, you may not be making the best ones and therefore missing out on opportunities.
You don't let second thoughts get in the way of taking action, which makes you see opportunities others might miss.

content.text: New story text
content.question: 4. Do you worry about the future and constantly analyze things in your past?

explanation.text: You’re constantly thinking of the past or future and not living in the present. You might hold yourself back because of this fear.
Don’t allow fear to stop you from taking the actions necessary for success.

content.text: New story text
content.question: 5. Do you replay conversations in your head and obsess over what someone thought about something you said?

explanation.text: You’re putting a lot of pressure on yourself to be perfect. But there's no such thing as perfect!
Keep moving forward and use your mistakes to grow.

content.text: When you overthink, your thoughts become so excessive and obsessive that it’s hard to concentrate on anything else. It’s almost like your brain is stuck in a loop, repeating the same thoughts over and over again. Overthinking can be a self-destructive habit that leaves us feeling anxious, depressed, or alone. So why do we overthink?

The connections we make in our brains during learning help us understand new information. As a result, the more you think about something—whether it's a challenge at work or your feelings for someone special—the stronger these connections become! This process allows us to gain a better perspective on things—including ourselves.

Overthinking can also help us feel more in control. The more we think about something, the less likely it is that something will happen by chance. This can be particularly helpful if you’re trying to avoid making a bad decision or doing something risky.

Overthinking can be helpful in some situations but can also be harmful. You may miss other important things if you’re too focused on one thing. For example, you may be so focused on what you’re going to say next that you don’t notice that the person you’re talking to has stopped listening.
New story text
content.question: What is a positive effect of overthinking?

explanation.text: Overthinking causes us to spend more time thinking about what could happen than actually doing something.
Overthinking can help you thoroughly think through a problem or situation and find solutions.
When overthinking, we often stay in one place mentally rather than progressing towards a goal.

content.text: Overthinking has some benefits, but the adverse effects significantly impact our lives. When we overthink, it’s easy to get caught up in stress or anxiety and become less productive. We might also lose sight of what's important in life, like spending time with friends or working towards our goals. Or fail to notice the things that are right in front of us. Now let's enter the world of Olivia and Izaak.

One night, Olivia went out with her friends while her boyfriend, Izaak, stayed home. She told Izaak where she was going and what time to expect her back at home—but he worried anyway. He imagined she could be lying or put their relationship in danger, so he felt jealous and anxious.

Izaak imagined many scenarios of what could go wrong, so he grew increasingly jealous and anxious. At first, he didn't share these feelings. He also didn't seek reassurance from Olivia, which made him even more insecure. Eventually, Izaak began arguing with Olivia and thought he was losing her love.

Their relationship was strained, and they fought often. Olivia felt confused and hurt by Izaak's behavior; she didn't understand why he wasn't acting like himself. Overthinking had taken their bond to the brink of breakup.

Izaak finally opened up about his feelings. He realized that his overthinking had been causing him to lose sight of what was important in his relationship with Olivia. They were both happier when he started talking to her about his feelings, stopped worrying about how things would end up and just enjoyed being with her.
Izaak worked on overcoming his problems with overthinking. Olivia was supportive throughout the process, bringing them closer together in the end. Let's take a look at how he did it!

First, Izaak considered what he was thinking about when his mind wandered (which happened often). He realized that many of these thoughts were not worth his attention. Izaak started writing all his thoughts in a notebook so he wouldn't have to keep them bottled up inside of him.

Once Izaak finished writing, he read through what he’d written to see if there was anything negative and unproductive on the page. If so, he crossed it out with big red lines to avoid being distracted by those thoughts later and keep his mind clear. He then reread the page, highlighting any productive or positive thoughts.
New story text
content.question: Help Izaak find the positive thought. Which thought should be highlighted?

answerOptions.text: What if she meets someone better? Is she going to leave me?

explanation.text: Izaak should cross this thought out because it makes him feel insecure and like he’s not good enough.

answerOptions.text: I tend to overreact quite often. What can I do to be more trusting?

explanation.text: This is a good thought because it shows that Izaak is looking for ways to improve himself.

answerOptions.text: Doesn't she want to spend time with me? Do I seem boring?

explanation.text: Here, Izaak is making assumptions that may or may not be true.

answerOptions.text: I bet her friends are laughing at me right now.

explanation.text: Izaak can’t control other people's thoughts and feelings, so wasting time and energy worrying about them makes no sense.

content.text: Izaak has found a way to organize his thoughts and keep track of them, so he no longer feels stressed. Now he can focus on the problem at hand instead of being distracted by all those unimportant things that used to occupy his mind when he was feeling overwhelmed.

Overthinking can be exhausting and stressful. But if the constant worrying makes it difficult for you to relax, sleep, or concentrate on your work—it's time to make a change. Fortunately, you can regain control of your mind by following our five steps. If Izaak can do it, so can you!

content.header: Step 1: Pay attention to your thoughts
content.text: Think of your thoughts as little bubbles that float by. Each bubble can be a thought, an emotion, or a sensation in your body. Watch each bubble as it floats by. You don’t have to grab onto the bubbles but simply watch them pass by.

Pay attention to what happens as you watch the bubbles. The bubbles may change color, move faster or slower than before—or disappear altogether! Remember that your thoughts are not facts: they are just a collection of words and images, nothing more. Practice this exercise for five to 10 minutes a day.

content.header: Step 2: Focus on one thing at a time
content.text: It’s easy for your mind to jump from one idea to another without stopping for breath—especially when there’s so much going on in this world! But when you focus on one thing at a time, it becomes easier to manage stress and worry.

Here's an achievable task. Find a timer. Then pick one boring chore- making your bed or doing the dishes—and give it your full attention for 10 minutes while ignoring other thoughts and distractions. (It might seem impossible at first, but you'll be surprised by how quickly time passes.) Small additions like instrumental music can help you at the start, but try to do this task without any help as you progress.

When you notice a negative or unhelpful thought spiral, try to stop it by saying “stop” out loud or in your mind. Then, take an intentional pause. Notice what you feel in your body. Is it tight, relaxed, or somewhere in between? How do you feel emotionally? Try to become aware of each sensation as it arises and passes away.
Once you notice negative thoughts or feelings, try to shift your attention away from them.
New story text
content.question: Which affirmation is NOT a good example?

explanation.text: This statement is vague and a bit judgmental rather than action-oriented. Try to be more specific. Focus on the positive or what you want to achieve.

answerOptions.text: “I have a negative thought, but I will not let it ruin my day.”

explanation.text: This is good because it's specific and reminds you that you're in control.

answerOptions.text: “That thought is not helpful; I don’t need to think about it now.”

explanation.text: Being specific tells you what to do and helps you take action.

answerOptions.text: “That’s just my brain trying to be creative right now.”

explanation.text: This is positive, affirming, and gives you a reason to smile!

answerOptions.text: “That’s just my mind trying to worry again.”

explanation.text: Here, you're acknowledging what’s happening, which can help you detach from the thought and let it go.

content.text: Here’s an example, "I am not good enough." Challenge this thought by asking yourself what evidence there is for it. If you're not good enough for your partner, why do they stay with you? If you're not good enough for someone else's approval, then what about the people in your life who already love and support you?

As you write your thoughts, you may want some help to determine which ones are important and which aren't. Here are some questions to ask yourself. 
1) What is this thought trying to tell me? 
2) How do I feel when I think this way? 
3) Why do I care about this? 
4) Is it important or just interesting? 
5) Is this my problem or someone else’s?

content.header: You’re in control of your mind
content.text: By understanding the role that overthinking plays in your life and learning new ways to cope, you can lower its impact and live a more peaceful existence!

Although our sessions will end, don't despair! Next time, we'll go over everything we've covered so that you leave feeling confident and prepared. You're closer than ever before to experiencing bliss and happiness. See you there!
Thoughts are like an open ocean, they can either move you forward within its waves or sink you under deep into its abyss.
content.title: Anthony Liccione

episodes.title: Wrap up: keep emotions in check
episodes.description: Daily steps to radiate calm and balance

content.text: New story text
content.question: Welcome, friend! How are you feeling?

explanation.text: Happiness is a journey, not a destination. So let’s continue exploring ways to feel even better and happier than ever!
It's okay not to feel super happy all the time. We're here to give you a boost and help you be happier!
Feeling down is a common experience. But with the right mindset and tools, you can find happiness again!

content.text: New story text
content.question: Have you been practicing techniques we’ve covered?

explanation.text: You’re learning to acknowledge and accept feelings that have been difficult to understand.
If you want to create a calm, peaceful life for yourself, it's essential to practice.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Has your relationship with your feelings improved?

explanation.text: Your feelings are a great source of information, and when you listen to what they say, you'll get some fantastic insights about yourself and your life.
As you get more in touch with your feelings, it'll become easier for you to recognize them. Keep practicing the techniques we've taught you!

content.text: There are plenty of ways to deal with your feelings, but avoiding them by distracting yourself by watching television or working too hard is unhealthy. It is also harmful to suppress them by bottling up your emotions so you don't have to feel them. Labeling your emotions is a healthy practice and an excellent way to gain insight into your feelings.
New story text
content.question: What’s a correct example of labeling emotions?

answerOptions.text: "I'm feeling sad because I've been procrastinating."

explanation.header: This explains why, but not how sad you are.
explanation.text: Labeling your feelings, and noting the intensity of those emotions, can help you more accurately assess a situation and respond to it appropriately.

answerOptions.text: "I spend hours on social media and end up feeling guilty."

explanation.header: This is an example of self-awareness, not emotional labeling.
explanation.text: Self-awareness is the ability to monitor your thoughts and feelings. Emotional labeling refers to naming an emotion or recognizing its intensity.

answerOptions.text: "I’m feeling so anxious that I'm going to faint."

explanation.text: Emotional labeling can help identify the true source of your feelings and refocus them in more productive ways by describing the intensity of your feelings.

explanation.header: Good example of positive self-talk, not emotional labeling.
explanation.text: Emotional labeling differs from positive self-talk because it describes the intensity of your feeling at a given moment, not just its presence.

content.text: Nick is a great guy who's always cheerful and supportive, but sadly, he only sees his faults. He often says things to himself like, "I'm not good enough to be your friend," or "I don't deserve to be in this relationship."
New story text
content.question: Nick is probably struggling with __________.

explanation.text: Nick isn’t directing his anger at anyone else. He just feels negative about himself and the way things are going.
Nick isn’t afraid of anything in particular. It's more that he thinks that he's not good enough.
Nick isn’t trying to solve a problem or find answers. Instead, he's just beating himself up.
Negative self-talk is a series of thoughts that lead us to believe that we are not good enough. It's a way of thinking that often leads to depression, anxiety, and other mental health issues.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Let’s help Nick. Turn this negative thought into a positive affirmation: "I don't deserve to be in this relationship."

answerOptions.text: “I deserve to be loved by someone.”

explanation.text: This implies that you’re not loved, which is a negative thought.

answerOptions.text: "I am worthy of love and belonging; I’ll meet someone who sees that."

explanation.text: It affirms your worthiness while acknowledging that you may not have found love yet. Accepting the reality of your situation without falling into negative thought patterns is important.
Specific goals are easier to achieve than broad ones because they provide a concrete path to success.

answerOptions.text: "Love will find me. I am perfect as I am.”

explanation.text: This puts the responsibility for finding love on “love” and not yourself. You’re responsible for your happiness, so affirm that you will find a partner who accepts you for who you are.

content.text: The six-step process of turning around self-defeating thinking is recognizing, recording, and organizing negative thoughts. Turn them into positive statements and repeat them. Ready, set—act! Take steps to turn your affirmations into reality. Finally, identify situations that trigger negative self-talk and see if there are patterns.

Negative thoughts can trigger anxiety. Anxiety is marked by feelings of panic and dread, constant worry about the future—and overthinking those worries so much that it interferes with your ability to sleep at night or function normally during the day. It can also cause physical symptoms, such as headaches and muscle tension.
New story text
content.question: You may be experiencing healthy anxiety if

answerOptions.text: You cannot remember what to say during a presentation.

explanation.text: If anxiety erases the hard work that you've done, then this is not healthy.

answerOptions.text: You throw up before every exam.

explanation.text: Since this physical illness is not helping you perform better (and may hinder your performance), it has become unhealthy anxiety.

answerOptions.text: You feel nervous before an interview.

explanation.text: Feeling nervous can keep your mind sharp and focused on what to say next.

answerOptions.text: You’re so worried about finances you cannot sleep.

explanation.text: Unhealthy anxiety can make it difficult for you to sleep or concentrate—making it hard for you to function at work and in your personal life. It can also lower self-esteem and make career prospects less likely.

content.text: New story text
content.question: What’s a good way of dealing with anxiety?

explanation.header: Great choice - all the choices are great!
explanation.text: It's important to understand what causes your anxiety because it can help you identify what triggers it and how to manage it better.

explanation.header: This works - all the choices work!
explanation.text: Doing something active is one of the best ways to manage anxiety because it helps you to focus on the present moment.

explanation.header: Highly recommended - like the other choices!
explanation.text: Simple, inexpensive techniques like deep breathing and progressive muscle relaxation can help ease anxiety.

explanation.header: Try this one - and all the choices today!
explanation.text: Talking about your feelings with someone who understands what you're going through can be a source of strength and comfort.

explanation.header: A wonderful option - all the choices are!
explanation.text: Talk to a counselor if your friends and family aren’t providing enough support.

content.text: Managing anxiety is a complex process, and different people respond well to different approaches. One day, you might go for a run or listen to music; another may involve taking yoga classes or meeting with your therapist. The key is to try new things, be flexible and keep an open mind.
Like anxiety, guilt and regret are negative emotions. Imagine this scenario: you feel tired at work because you stayed up late playing video games last night.
New story text
content.question: This is:

explanation.text: Regret is a sense of sadness, disappointment, or sorrow over something that has happened or been done.
Guilt is the feeling that you have done something wrong.

content.text: Acknowledging feelings of guilt and regret, as well as accepting responsibility for your actions, is an essential first step to getting on with life. But it's also crucial to forgive yourself to heal past mistakes. That’s where self-compassion comes in—it helps us move forward by letting go of negative emotions so we can embrace the future instead!
New story text
content.question: Self-compassion can help! Which statement is a good email of it?

answerOptions.text: “I should be able to do this by now.”

explanation.text: This is not self-compassion because it focuses on self-blame and judgment.

answerOptions.text: “The first step is always the hardest, but everything will fall into place."

explanation.text: Staying positive, focusing on your strengths, and practicing self-compassion will help you overcome guilt or regret.

answerOptions.text: “I am having a hard time with this.”

explanation.text: This statement focuses on feelings of inadequacy and failure. Try again!

content.header: How anger is good for us
content.text: Guilt, regret, and anger are often uncomfortable feelings we experience when something goes wrong. However, they can also benefit us—if we learn from them.
New story text
content.question: Choose a scenario where anger can be beneficial.

explanation.text: Losing your temper after someone makes an innocent mistake can cause you to attack the person unfairly.

answerOptions.text: A friend is late for dinner.

explanation.text: Anger isn’t the proper response to a friend’s tardiness. Your friend may have had a valid reason for being late.
Your anger made you brave enough to stand up for your friend in this situation.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Choose the best strategy for dealing with anger.

answerOptions.text: Staying silent or passive when you’re angry.

explanation.text: Not only does this make things worse, but it can also lead to more arguments in the future.

answerOptions.text: Blaming yourself for being too sensitive or having no control.

explanation.text: This can make you feel even more frustrated, making it harder to deal with your anger healthily.
You may do something that makes matters worse or doesn’t help solve the problem.
This is a productive way of dealing with anger because it helps you understand the root cause and why it’s important to you.

answerOptions.text: Thinking about what happened and why.

explanation.text: Dwelling on these thoughts may lead you to the wrong conclusions about what happened.

answerOptions.text: Hiding away from the situation that caused the anger.

explanation.text: Doing this allows the anger to fester and grow without any outlet for expression.

content.text:
It is better to express anger healthily than let it build up inside you. Here are our top three tips. 
1) Take a walk outside or do some stretching, even if it's just around your living room. 
2) Close your eyes and breathe deeply through your nose as you exhale slowly through pursed lips. 
3) Laugh. Humor is always a great way to boost moods!

Andy can't decide which university to attend. He's overwhelmed by "analysis paralysis," a state of mind in which he cannot make any decisions because he keeps thinking about all the possible outcomes and becoming paralyzed by indecision.
New story text
content.question: Andy likely is

explanation.text: Andy isn’t experiencing strong emotions of shame, embarrassment, and self-loathing as he thinks about everything he should’ve done differently.
Andy is stuck in a mental loop and can't even begin making the decision he needs to make. Andy would benefit from writing down his thoughts and crossing out the unhelpful ones.
He’s not overwhelmed by anxious feelings but by too many thoughts about how he should act.

content.text: New story text
content.question: Let’s help Andy! He wrote a few of his thoughts. Which one is positive?

answerOptions.text: “I should be further along in my education by now.”

explanation.text: This thought does nothing to move Andy forward. Rewrite it: “I am proud of myself for working hard and doing my best.”

answerOptions.text: “My teachers never said anything positive about my work.”

explanation.text: Thoughts like this can make Andy feel discouraged. Rewrite it: "I can do anything if I put my mind to it.”

answerOptions.text: “I wish I had more money to attend a private university."

explanation.text: This prevents Andy from focusing on what needs to be done. Rewrite it: "I have many resources to help me reach my goals.”

answerOptions.text: “Life is full of opportunities, but only if I make them happen.”

explanation.text: It reminds Andy that he’s in control of his life and how it turns out.

content.text: Train yourself to watch your thoughts, emotions, and physical sensations as if bubbles pass by. Focus on one thing at a time by doing something boring—such as mopping the floor or washing dishes—mindfully for 10 minutes every day. If you catch yourself falling into a negative thought pattern, say “stop” out loud or in your mind. Then shift away from negativity by challenging the thoughts or writing them down.

We're proud of you for making it through this course! This work can be hard sometimes, but it's worth the effort. You've taken an essential first step towards building a better life. You’ve got this. Keep going, and know that you are not alone. You have an amazing community of support behind you.

We hope you continue to learn and grow as you journey through life. The more knowledge you gain, the better equipped you are to make wonderful decisions for yourself—and those around you. We wish you everything good and send our love until we meet again. Goodbye!
When embraced and accepted, negative emotions can be a powerful catalyst to positive change in one’s life and can lead to a deeper feeling of meaning and authenticity.
content.title: Paul Wong

card.title: Anti-Burnout Plan: Revive The Drive
card.description: Reduce exhaustion and stress, regain energy and motivation

preview.title: Anti-Burnout Plan: Revive The Drive
preview.overview:
Are you feeling drained and stuck in that never-ending stress cycle? Work and responsibilities leave you exhausted, your motivation and productivity drop down, and you don't know what to do? You might be experiencing burnout. 

In this course, we offer science-based techniques, simple exercises, and expert insights to help you learn how to alleviate stress, regain motivation, and manage your energy to reduce the burden of burnout. 

Join now and make the first step towards a brighter, happier and more productive life.

episodes.title: Understanding Burnout
episodes.description: Uncover burnout's silent signs and pave your way to freedom

content.text: Today, we're exploring a complex maze called "burnout". Ever felt paralyzed by the weight of work, not just on your shoulders but also in your mind and heart? Endless stress, the chronic kind that drowns you in overwhelm? That's burnout we're talking about.

Think about it, reflect on it. Could this be happening to you? If so, don't worry. You're not alone in this and don't have to walk through it alone. We're here with you, step by step, breath by breath, because you matter. Now, let's talk about burnout.

Burnout mainly results from constant work-related stress but can also occur in other areas of life. Key symptoms include chronic fatigue, lower productivity, disconnection or indifference, and feeling overwhelmed.

content.header: Have you experienced any of these feelings?
content.text: New story text
content.question: Have you experienced any of these feelings?

explanation.text: Let's work through it together.

explanation.header: It's a hurdle, but you're not alone.
explanation.text: Let's start healing step by step.
Together, we'll build your resilience.

content.text: Constant hustle and the fear of losing progress often make us spiral into the burnout trap. We push ourselves to the limit to maintain outcomes, but this pressure can severely affect our well-being.
New story text
content.question: Why is self-awareness important in preventing burnout?

explanation.text: Self-awareness is very important in stopping burnout.
With self-awareness, you can spot burnout signs early.

answerOptions.text: It’s a quick fix for burnout

explanation.text: Self-awareness isn't a quick fix; it's only the first step. Let's rethink this.

content.text: Awareness of your personal state helps address issues before they escalate. This awareness provides insight into our physical, emotional, and mental states, paving the way for a balanced and fulfilling life. Let us take a look at Sarah, whose experience with burnout has led her to embrace the importance of self-awareness and balance.

Sarah's life teetered on the brink, with the stresses of her fast-paced job in the tech industry casting shadows on her once-bright spirits. Drained and overwhelmed, she found herself losing grip on the simplest tasks. The fears of losing her job and the relentless overthinking only added to her burdens.
New story text
content.question: How do you think burnout affected Sara’s personal life?

explanation.text: Experiencing burnout typically leads to a decrease in joy and energy. Let's try another answer!
Burnout might cause stress in personal relations and emotional difficulties.
Burnout can hurt personal relationships. Give it another shot!

content.text: In the chaos that seemed to have no end, Sarah's connections with those closest to her began to falter as she drifted away emotionally. Can things take a turn for the better? Is this cycle predetermined to continue infinitely?

Kevin, Sarah's husband, couldn't help but notice the turmoil consuming his wife. Rallying his love and concern, he dove headfirst into understanding the complexities that were causing Sarah's distress. For nights on end, his weary eyes scanned article after article until he unraveled the answer: burnout.

As Sarah listened to Kevin's insights, a fresh perspective started to blossom before her. Instead of her usual mirror of stress and weariness, she saw renewed potential. In the quietest corners of her heart, she asked herself, "Isn't there more to life than this nonstop tiredness?"
New story text
content.question: How could noticing burnout change Sarah's life?

explanation.text: Noticing burnout could significantly influence her decisions.
Noticing burnout can lead to positive shifts and smarter choices for Sarah.

content.text: The possibility of redirecting her career path and healing her strained relationships seemed not only possible but vital. With determination igniting her spirit, Sarah resolved to evoke change in her life and banish burnout once and for all.

content.header: The power of self-care against burnout
content.text: Sarah reflected, "By taking care of myself, I've become my own strongest supporter in the fight against burnout. Even though it was difficult, using the right methods and tools helped me overcome it." Her success shows the real strength of self-reliance. Sarah balanced her career and relationships, creating a future where both can thrive together.

Drawing inspiration from Sarah's transformative journey, let's bravely navigate the path of self-discovery. Your first task in this process is an insightful Daily Self Check-In, a purposely crafted, 3-step activity that serves as a tool to prevent burnout, create self-worth, and foster an environment for self-care and self-love.

content.header: Today’s task: a simple path to increased self-awareness
content.text: Ready to embark on an empowering journey of self-discovery? In this course, we're going to provide simple tasks to help eliminate burnout, starting with our captivating three-step Daily Self Check-In. Here's the roadmap to guide you on this transformative task!

1. Find a quiet space and moment during your day.
2. Take a few deep breaths to center yourself.
3. Ask yourself these questions:

- Physically: How am I feeling today? Any aches or tiredness?
- Emotionally: What is my emotional state? How am I coping with my emotions?
- Mentally: Am I experiencing any intense stress or tension? How focused am I?

Reflect on your interactions with family and co-workers, noting any short-tempered or impatient behavior. Recognize that burnout has various causes, some uncontrollable. Jot down your thoughts and address any issues. This simple activity helps avoid burnout, supports balance, and shows you have the power to succeed.

Remember, this practice isn't about immediate solutions but developing awareness. Keep practicing the Daily Self Check-In and stay in tune with your well-being. Your journey to prevent burnout starts with these small yet powerful steps. Join us in the next Episode where we'll explore the roots of burnout and discuss its triggers in detail.

Rest is not idleness, and to lie sometimes on the grass under trees on a summer's day, listening to the murmur of the water, or watching the clouds float across the sky, is by no means a waste of time.
content.title: John Lubbock

episodes.title: Burnout Triggers
episodes.description: Learn to spot them and reclaim control

content.text: Have you ever felt like you're drifting in a vast ocean, with each wave of responsibilities threatening to pull you under? This overwhelming exhaustion is what we call burnout. It's been tiring physically, emotionally and mentally. Isn't it time we face this issue? With a brave heart and a curious mind, let's explore the hidden causes of burnout.

Is your work and home environment weighing you down? It's easy to feel pushed towards burnout between excessive workload, home responsibilities, child or elder care, and high-pressure demands. A lack of support in these areas can multiply our stress, making us more vulnerable to burnout.

Burnout can creep in when we push ourselves too hard. Let's remember the "work endlessly" mindset, or “hustle culture”, doesn't truly serve us. We need and deserve peaceful moments to rest and rejuvenate. It's okay not to be perfect or busy all the time!
New story text
content.question: How is the hustle culture related to burnout?

explanation.text: Remember, balance is the key to managing burnout.

answerOptions.text: It can trigger burnout if not managed properly

explanation.text: Keeping an eye on balance can make all the difference.

answerOptions.text: It provides the necessary stress to perform

explanation.text: It's true that stress can sometimes boost performance, but let's remember it's important to take breaks, too.

content.text: Stress at work and home, perfectionism, and intense productivity cause burnout. Isn't it time to break free? Change isn't only external; it's mental, too. Now, let’s meet Ben. Like us, he's grappling with burnout. Ready to join his journey?

He's just like you, trying to balance dreams and responsibilities. But his passion is slowly fading. Ben faces a heavy workload, constantly chasing perfection and worrying about time slipping away. Can you see yourself in Ben's story?

Ben takes his first step towards change. He identified his stress triggers: late-night work, skipped meals, and non-stop notifications. These were silently burning him out. Like Ben, can you pinpoint what fuels your fatigue and choose to change?

Ben's journey is not a quick fix but a gradual transformation: identifying his stress triggers, embracing his flaws, recognizing his limits, and speaking kindly to himself. His battle against burnout isn't just a fight; it's his new definition of success. Are you ready to learn from Ben's story, dig deep, and find the sources of your stress?
New story text
content.question: According to Ben's story, what is the first step to combating burnout?

explanation.text: Identifying your stress triggers is the first crucial step; knowing what you're up against is empowering.

explanation.header: No, ignoring a problem rarely solves it
explanation.text: Acknowledging your stress is a positive first step on your journey to wellness!
Working harder isn't the answer; it's about working smarter by first recognizing what causes stress!

content.text: Feel overwhelmed by life's stresses? You might be dealing with an enormous workload, just like many others. This could be your primary stress trigger. Is it an endless to-do list? A struggle for work-life balance or lack of self-love? Reflect, identify your triggers, and write them down.

Next, divide your triggers into controllable and uncontrollable groups. Your heavy workload is a controllable trigger. Addressing this with a work plan can make a significant difference. Overcommitment might also be a trigger. Learning to say 'no' when your plate is full, prioritizing tasks, and avoiding overextending yourself will help.

content.header: What to do with the uncontrollable triggers?
content.text: Recognize what can’t be changed and put energy into areas where you can make a difference to reduce burnout. Applying stress-management strategies, like meditation, breathing techniques, and grounding, can dramatically improve your well-being and reduce burnout. You can practice these strategies today; just check out our 28-day Burnout Relief & Relaxation audio course after you finish this episode!

The journey to burnout recovery isn't necessarily about massive revisions to our lives. Small changes, the ones that feel "doable," can make a significant impact. Importantly, know that it's okay to ask for help, and always remember to be kind and patient with yourself.
New story text
content.question: How should you make changes to help with burnout?

explanation.text: Too many changes at once can increase burnout. Slow, steady steps work best.
Adding changes bit by bit helps beat burnout. Start with one or two areas for easy adjustment.

answerOptions.text: Change your entire lifestyle at once

explanation.text: Quick, total changes can stress you out more. Small, gradual changes bring better progress.

content.text: Burnout creeps into our lives through various paths, subtly and seamlessly. But empowerment begins with awareness. Let's revisit some common triggers and add a few new ones. Understanding and acknowledging these triggers can be the first step towards overcoming burnout.

1. Excessive workload: working too much without a break 
2. Perfectionism: trying to be perfect all the time 
3. Lack of support: feeling alone or unsupported 
4. Unhealthy lifestyle: ignoring physical health through bad habits like desk dining and lack of movement 
5. Negative self-talk: always criticizing yourself and decreasing self-esteem

1. The hustle culture: the need to always be productive and continuously outperform ourselves 
2. Lack of control: feeling unable to influence decisions in your work or personal life can foster feelings of helplessness
3. Work-life imbalance: compromising personal time for work-related tasks 
4. Emotional intelligence loss: difficulty in managing and processing emotional reactions
5. Internal dialogue: your internal dialogue, perceptions of coworker feedback, polarized thinking, and reactions to specific individuals.

You did great today! Remember, we're all a work in progress. In the next episode, we tackle overthinking, a murky burnout accomplice. You’ll learn techniques to ease your overworked mind. Stay tuned, friend. You're stronger than you realize.
You have power over your mind, not outside events. Realize this, and you will find strength.
content.title: Marcus Aurelius

episodes.title: Taming Overthinking
episodes.description: Find calm and clarity by breaking free from racing thoughts

content.text: Welcome to Episode 3! Ever felt like your mind won't stop racing no matter how hard you try? Does it feel like your thoughts control you, not the other way around? If so, you’re in the right place.

Overthinking can contribute to burnout, but don't worry. Let's gently unravel your thoughts using simple calming techniques that are based on science. Embrace these soothing tools to find relief and effectively overcome burnout. You've got this!
New story text
content.question: How do you think overthinking contributes to burnout?

explanation.text: Think about how constant mental replay of worries and doubts might affect your emotional state and stress levels in the long run.

answerOptions.text: It has little effect on your well-being

explanation.text: Overthinking can affect both mental and emotional health. It often leads to exhaustion and burnout.

answerOptions.text: It increases stress and drains your energy

explanation.text: Overthinking can be draining and stressful, contributing to burnout.

content.text: Overthinking involves excessively analyzing or worrying about situations, thoughts, or conversations. It can be mentally exhausting, evoking anxiety and contributing to burnout if left unchecked.

Burnout is when you feel exhausted in your mind and emotions. You start to question the value of your efforts or the likelihood of positive results and feel as if you're not achieving much. Overthinking worsens this by adding stress and reducing your ability to think.

Overthinking feeds into a vicious cycle of anxiety and stress, further contributing to burnout symptoms. Identifying and tackling it is crucial when addressing and preventing burnout. Now, let’s explore the tale of someone who struggled with overthinking and neared burnout.

Let's meet Mark, a hard-working professional. Mark felt his enthusiasm and productivity dropping. His high standards and fear of failure led to obsessive overthinking that dominated his life. His nonstop thinking was not only tiring him out but also pushing him towards burnout quickly.

Mark’s overthinking started small but soon took over completely. He was trapped in a whirlwind of constant "what ifs," which robbed him of his peace. It affected not only his work but also strained his personal relationships. His health suffered too, with sleepless nights and rising stress levels.

Feeling burned out, Mark decided to seek help. He discovered and learned several ways to help manage his mental stress. With these techniques, he began to identify his overthinking patterns and took small steps towards change. These helpful changes allowed him to shift from negative thinking to a more positive mindset.

Despite being talented, Mark felt crushed under his own thoughts. But then, he found techniques that helped him stop his overthinking. Want to know what Mark discovered? Keep going; we're about to reveal the techniques that changed his life.
Practice mindfulness by recognizing your thoughts without judgment. Notice when you're overthinking about the past or future concerns. Ask yourself, "Is this currently relevant, or can I let it go?"
Gently redirect your attention once you spot overthinking. Calmly and kindly remind yourself: "This is unproductive. I trust that I will find a solution when the time comes."

Persistently practice mindfulness to avoid spiraling into overthinking. Remember, your aim isn't to eliminate thoughts but to navigate through with more clarity and control. Strive for progress over perfection.
New story text
content.question: How can mindfulness help combat overthinking?

explanation.text: Mindfulness does not promote self-criticism. Instead, it encourages self-compassion and acceptance!

answerOptions.text: It encourages ruminating on past events

explanation.text: Mindfulness is focused on the present moment, reducing the tendency to brood over past events.

answerOptions.text: It helps you observe your thoughts without judgment

explanation.text: Mindfulness does allow you to observe your thoughts in a non-judgmental way, helping you manage overthinking effectively. Now let’s consider how you can be more mindful and overcome overthinking. Check out these Top 9 Tips!

content.header: Top 9 tips to stop overthinking, part 1/3
content.text:
1. Acknowledge your successes: regularly reflect on your past achievements. Create a success journal to track your progress, no matter how small or large. It boosts confidence and quiets overthinking.
2. Remind yourself of your strengths and worth: know that it's completely okay to be imperfect - everyone is. Don't focus solely on your shortcomings. Remind yourself of what you're good at. 
3. Welcome a different perspective: when you find that you're replaying events in your mind over and over, or worrying about things you can't change, ask yourself, “Is there another viewpoint for this situation?”

4. Limit your checking and re-checking: it's not unusual to second-guess yourself or your work. Ask a trusted friend, colleague, or family member to review your work and provide feedback instead of checking it over and over yourself.
5. Curb exposure to information: avoid information overload by reducing the time you spend on news, social media, and technology. Set aside specific times for checking these sources.
6. Engage in relaxing activities: allocate time for hobbies and activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as reading, painting, or gardening. These activities serve as distractions and help restore mental balance.

7. Practice gratitude: cultivate a gratitude practice by acknowledging the positive aspects of your life and work. Recognizing what's going well can help shift your perspective.
8. Get adequate sleep: good quality sleep is crucial for maintaining mental and emotional well-being. Develop a consistent sleep schedule and follow proper sleep hygiene practices.
9. Seek support: share your concerns and challenges with friends, family, or a therapist. Talking about your thoughts can help put things in perspective.

Armed with techniques to tackle overthinking, you're now better equipped to counter burnout. Embrace calmness and mental clarity as you take charge of your thoughts and transform your life. Join us in the next episode as we talk about your energy drainers and what you can do about them!
The greatest weapon against stress is our ability to choose one thought over another
content.title: William James

episodes.title: Energy Management
episodes.description: Identify & minimize your energy drainers

content.text: Welcome to Episode 4! Do you know that heavy fog of exhaustion following energy-consuming tasks? Have you noticed a link between this draining fatigue and looming burnout? In this episode, we dive into such questions, exploring the bond between taxing tasks and burnout.
New story text
content.question: What would be your initial step in managing energy-draining tasks?

answerOptions.text: Identifying tasks that lead to fatigue

explanation.text: Understanding the source of our energy drains empowers us to make meaningful and targeted changes.
Reducing work hours might temporarily ease stress, but it doesn't address the root cause of our energy drains.
Avoidance doesn't resolve the issue; instead, it promotes fear and stagnancy in our personal growth.

content.text: Tasks aren't all equal, a simple truth we often forget. Some demand more of us, physically, emotionally, mentally, leeching energy. Let's master the act of finding these energy-hungry tasks and gracefully reclaim our peace of mind.

Energy-draining tasks can ignite burnout, hindering productivity and stealing joy from work. Recognizing this crucial connection is the first step towards overcoming burnout and reclaiming a fulfilling work life.

You're far from helpless when facing energy-drainers. Equipped with strategies like prioritization and task evaluation, you're poised to protect your vital energy and win the fight against burnout. Now, let’s talk about Vivian.

Vivian's story mirrors our own: overworking to the point of pure exhaustion, burnout lurking ominously nearby. She encounters energy-draining tasks that act as hidden shackles, weighing her down. Have you, too, stumbled along, unknowingly tending to these hidden energy leeches that drain your reserves?
A determined worker, Vivian tired and struggled to maintain her productivity, sensing burnout gaining on her. Desperate for change, she embarked on an energy self-discovery.

Vivian took a hard look, truly looked, at her daily tasks. Those long team meetings? Energy drainers. The endless emails and instant messages? Major energy thieves. By recognizing these, Vivian found new ways to approach her work, saving her treasured energy. How?

Energy management revealed which tasks drained Vivian the most. She started to rethink these tasks, questioning their necessity and considering alternative approaches leading to lighter energy consumption.

Can Vivian make team meetings more efficient? If not, she needs stress management strategies, like mindful breathing and calming tea. Is there a way to tame the wild beast that her inbox had become? Could she impose some order by setting designated email hours? The wheels began turning. Vivian transformed her despair into decisive action.
New story text
content.question: What was Vivian’s strategy for dealing with energy-draining tasks?

explanation.text: There are more sustainable solutions to managing energy-draining tasks than abandoning work.

answerOptions.text: She recognized and rethought her tasks

explanation.text: By identifying and reassessing her tasks, Vivian proactively took control of her energy management.

answerOptions.text: She delegated her tasks to others

explanation.text: While delegation can be helpful, there were other strategies Vivian employed in her energy management journey.

content.header: A new lease on work-life balance
content.text: Armed with a smarter approach to her energy, there was a significant shift in Vivian's work life. Her productivity surged, burnout was kept at bay, and a deep, profound love for her work surfaced. In this renewed energy landscape, Vivian thrived. You can thrive, too. Ready?
Start by pinpointing what or who is draining your energy. This could be a negative coworker or a difficult work project. Accept and understand that your energy levels are affected by this.

After identifying the drainer, establish boundaries. You could limit your interaction time with a negative individual or schedule regular breaks when dealing with a difficult task. Don't hesitate to seek and accept help from others when possible. For example, delegate some duties to your colleagues.

Next up is to regain your energy through self-care activities. You might exercise, indulge in a hobby, or take a break. Alongside this, reevaluate how you see the energy drainer. A simple change in outlook can give you a boost, such as seeing a tough task as a learning opportunity.

If after trying all steps, the energy drain continues, and it's something you can avoid, think about entirely removing it. You may, for example, have to end a harmful friendship. Remember, each step is about keeping your energy up while managing your responsibilities.

content.header: Soaring above burnout: your energy triumph
content.text: Well done! You're sparkling with new strategies and reflection, rising above burnout and enjoying a work-life balance fueled by preserved energy. Continue honestly and kindly, embracing a life rich in energy where you shine bright! Stay tuned for our next episode, where we discuss how self-compassion serves as a soothing balm for burnout.
Rest when you're weary. Refresh and renew yourself, your body, your mind, your spirit. Then get back to work.
content.title: Ralph Waldo Emerson

episodes.title: Cultivating Self-Compassion
episodes.description: Replace burnout with resilience through self-kindness

content.text: Are you tired and overwhelmed, friend? Do tasks feel like boulders on your weary shoulders, pushing you down? You're not alone in this struggle. In this episode, we'll explore together how gentle self-compassion can help disperse the fog of burnout.

Ready to break through the walls of self-doubt and let in the light of self-kindness? Ready to wave goodbye to burnout, welcoming kindness towards oneself as the sun rises on a new day? Remember, on this journey, you are seen. You are heard. And above all, you are stronger than you know. This is your moment; let us begin.

Burnout can lead to a myriad of symptoms: lack of motivation, depression, anxiety, physical illnesses, and more. Yet, even as you face these challenges, know that hope is nestled within; unearth it, and thrive anew.

Rushing to meet deadlines, strained relationships, and feelings of inadequacy are some red flags of burnout. As you face these challenges, let self-compassion be the key to unlock your inner fortitude.
New story text
content.question: What is self-compassion?

explanation.text: Self-compassion isn't about spoiling ourselves. It's about understanding and being kind to ourselves when things are tough.

answerOptions.text: Knowing our needs and dealing with problems kindly

explanation.text: Self-compassion involves understanding what we really need and tackling difficulties in a gentle way.

answerOptions.text: Not owning up to our actions

explanation.text: Self-compassion involves acknowledging our actions responsibly while treating ourselves with kindness and understanding.

content.text: Self-compassion is not an indulgence; it's understanding your true needs and dealing with challenges more gently. Embrace this life-altering act of self-care and let it serve as a guiding light towards healing.
New story text

explanation.text: Reducing self-criticism helps us be kinder to ourselves, which is a key part of self-compassion.
Reducing self-criticism isn't about feeling superior to others; it's about improving our own self-worth and understanding.

answerOptions.text: To avoid responsibility for our actions

explanation.text: Reducing self-criticism doesn't mean avoiding responsibility; it means dealing with our actions in a healthy and forgiving way.

content.question: What is the main goal of reducing self-criticism?

content.text: By reducing self-criticism, we can pave the pathway to self-compassion, which can lessen burnout. Are you prepared to question old negative beliefs and welcome change? Take inspiration from Jenny, whose story we'll share next.

Jenny, once full of energy, became consumed by burnout. She battled constant fatigue, a loss of appetite, and difficulty focusing, leading to irritability and a sense of isolation. Juggling with never-ending work, scarce breaks, and relentless self-doubt, Jenny's burnout symptoms intensified.

She grappled with emotional outbursts, disruptive sleep patterns, and a weakened physical state. When she found herself at rock bottom, it was self-compassion that emerged as the transformative and healing method she needed to feel better.

As Jenny applied this newfound gift, burnout gradually lost its grip on her. The gift of self-compassion allowed her to write a new chapter in her life story, brimming with personal and professional fulfillment. How?

Jenny began her journey by modifying her self-talk. She exchanged negative labels like "failure" for positive affirmations, such as "brave" as a result of embracing self-compassion. As she took more steps on this path, her life gradually tilted towards happiness and balance.

Against all odds, Jenny's productivity blossomed. She experienced more creativity, less stress, and greater satisfaction at work. All because she dared to let her heart patiently guide her through adversity.
New story text
content.question: How did Jenny begin her journey to healing?
